| Sociology                                                                                                                                                  | - **Irving Zeitlin**: socio was reaction to enlightenment (**ideology and dev of sociological theory**)<br>- Socio helps us not only to be more analytical but also understand individuals, groups and institutions around us as well as their interaction with each other<br>- Europe 3 phases of modernity<br>    - Dark age -> religious and God centric (no logic)<br>    - Emerged in response to **social and intellectual climate of Europe**<br>    - Sociology the Product of clash between enlightenment (individuals) and counter enlightenment ideas (society at core)<br>    - Enlightenment refers to the intellectual movement concerned with governance and economy<br>    - Dark ages and Era of enlightenment (intellectual movement) -> ideological modernity – **13-17 century**<br>    - Focus on humanism – human centric lifestyle. **INDIVIDUALISM empricisim and rationality**<br>    - **Led by**<br>        - Voltaire – free speech<br>        - Hobbes and locke – natural rights – life, liberty and property<br>        - Rousseau – general will (will of majority) + every one had one vote<br>        - Marry Wollstonecraft – life liberty and property for gender equality<br>        - Adam Smith – free market economy – laissez faire and invisible hand + progressive taxation + specialization and DOL<br>        - montesquie (separation of power and const),<br>    - Renaissance – rebirth driven by new thinking – upheaval of art, architecture, ideas, literature<br>    - French rev – political modernity – rule of law and citizenship – 18 century – liberal democracy and concept of republic<br>    - Industrial rev – technological modernity – An era which involved mass production, factory system and standardization of production<br>        - Led to separation of work and home (**sexual DOL**) and time based production + efficiency + bureaucracy<br>    - Scientific revolution -> Copernicus – hello centric theory and Kepler – elliptical theory<br>    - Modernity refers to departure from tradition driven by intellectual forces and characterized by individualism, equality, humanism, democracy, free market, nation state and empiricism,<br>    - | Common sense                                                                                                                                               | - Some say socio is diff from common sense; other say common sense closer to reality<br>- Common sense is shared knowledge<br>- Weber – routine knowledge of our everyday world and activities<br>- Alfred Schutz's phenomenological sociology, where it refers to organized and 'typified' stocks of taken-for-granted knowledge upon which activities<br>- Empirical, based on assumptions and presumption eg galileo and science (earth rotates around sun)<br>- Status quoist, social revolution<br>- Deeper insights vs prejudice<br>    - Peter Berger – debunking attitude to understand levels of reality in society vs what appears on surface<br>- Based on beliefs and culture, based on objective analysis<br>- Based on imagination, ignorance, prejudice<br>- Establish cause and effect relationship and developing theories<br>- Socio collected data on people life and questioned methods of society<br>- Local and temporal vs universal eg Somoa island women hard wired – common sense but not true for other places<br>- Assumptions vs evidence<br>- Intitutive vs objective<br>- Common sense – we don’t find pattern in seemingly diff things whereas common patterns in seemingly diff events (eg similarity in caste and race)<br>- For failure – we put blame on individual vs understand external factors causing influence (sociological imagination)<br>- Use examples where common sense diff than socio – eg > married men and single men, suicide (psychological), higher caste more meritorious (observational) and poor as they are not qualified, but actually closed stratification and elite rule,<br>- Common sense perspectives: 1. Biological – women have maternal instinct; but Mead’s theory in “Sex and temperament in three primitive societies” reveals not universal<br>- mad people more delinquent vs white collar crime (white collar more – Sutherland)<br>- women more emo than men whereas conclude role of family and media in shaping gender<br>- Related – vocabulary (eg vote bank and role model) , hypothesis , common sense challenges socio – dynamically evolving<br>- In renaissance, common sense died<br>- Death of common sense leads to scientific society<br>- Make your model of reality<br>- Help in getting qualitative data eg – capitalism<br>- Not understand socio research otherwise<br>- Develop ideal type<br>- Helps in understanding socio theories<br>- Socio questions common sense eg religion dukrheim<br>- Locke – sensory organ is collecting data and when it is filtered through a rational mind, people look at the data with diff perception<br>- Beckers – labelling theory of sociology becomes common sense<br>- Gramsci – cultural hegemony of elite become common sense<br>- Refine common sense like vote bank, anticipatory socio (act like actor)<br><br>No gospel truths, hence multiple interpretations of society need to be accepted and common sense is an integral part to develop that unerstabding<br><br>CW Mills and sociological imagination<br><br>- SI as a tool to study social, external forces shape individual’s life<br>- An ability to explain social forces governing individual life<br>- He described 2 terms – personal issue (biography) and public issue (history)<br>    - Bio – a document on individual life<br>    - History – past or recent events<br>- But everything is a public issue and nothing is a personal issue<br>- Eg – crime and crime rate (Merton strain theory between culturally defined goals and socially available means), suicide and suicide rate (based on societal solidarity), divorce and divorce rate (service sector means financial indepdence for women)<br>- Socio imagination study rates and not actions<br>- These will depend on type of society and group membership<br>- Study external force instead<br>- Eg – sex ratio is skewed in Punjab and Haryana (bio); why? History -> Green rev + legalization of abortion + ultrasound tech -? led to individuals skewed sex ratio<br>    - Hence it is combining bio with history<br>- Suicide of individual -> history of society (modern or old) ; martyr vs competitiveness and isolation in modern societies<br>- Merton – American dream led to 1940 se increasing suicide<br>- Biography may also be read to study history | Scientific research                                                                                                                                        | - Scientific method is a logical and systematic method with steps to conduct scientific enquiry<br>    - Topic selection eg domestic abuse<br>    - Problem definition eg why – narrowed the problem<br>    - Preliminary research and existing literature review<br>    - Develop hypothesis – untested assumption<br>    - Operationalize variables in hypothesis ie explain the meaning of the variable<br>    - Choose research method – survey interview/ observation etc<br>    - Data collection and check validity and reliability of data<br>    - Analyze, Generalization and publish – hypothesis approve or refute<br>- Critique of science and scientific method<br>    - Multicausality in social world; however restrict variables<br>    - Inter mixture of cause and effect -> poverty and alcoholism<br>    - Difficult to quantify the data<br>    - Difficult to establish reliability<br>    - Karl Popper – many statements and hypothesis in social science are not falsifiable and hence not scientific<br>        - Eg Freud’s 3 layers in cognition – ID, ego, superego<br>        - Karl Marx – said fully developed society like Europe will be first place to have communist revolution. This is falsifiable . but revolution is not coming because people are living in false consciousness is not falsifiable<br>    - Paul Feyerbend – in reality, many scientists are not going with scientist method, rather dream experiences, assumptions or chance experiments (madam Curie chance experiment)<br>    - Thomas Kuhn – science undergoes paradigm shift where one theory is replaced by another but however in science, there is always one dominant paradigm. In social world, there is no one dominant paradigm and hence socio is not mature science but young science | Positivism and critique (other theoretical schools)                                                                                                        | - Positivism – cause and effect relationship that can be observed to define fixed laws of society such as in natural sciences. Philosophy which considers society exists like a natural system with inst such as family, state, law etc and has natural laws<br><br>Features - TOCQI<br><br>- Assumes society exists naturally out there<br>- They will objectively collect data<br>- Finds correlation between variables and develops causal grand theories (generalization)<br>- It believes social world to be driven by single cause (mono causal)<br>- Try to predict behaviour<br>- Focus only on observable facts and considers other factors such as motivations ad meanings as inconsequential<br>- Comte defined positivism in 2 ways:<br>    - As a doctrine (a philosophy) or as a method (research methodology)<br>- Science – organized body of knowledge where facts are inter-connected to each other on basis of which conclusion are established<br>- Features of socio as a science (TOQI)<br>    - Empirical<br>    - Based on theory<br>    - Objective<br>    - Testable<br>    - Use scientific methods<br>    - Use deductive approach and empiricism<br>    - Reliability and replicability<br>- Then why socio is science – positivism<br><br>![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 9.png>)<br><br>- - Definition, Features, example<br>- How weber concludes socio as science<br>    - Weber – socio is science as far as concerned with study of social actions, its causes and consequences objectively<br>        - What makes interpretive socio scientific -> qualitative data in a value-neutral manner<br>        - Social world by causal probabilism as there is one necessary cause eg – protestant ethics was a necessary cause<br>        - Every interpretivist socio accepts that they cant study the world as is; so study the model of social world (ideal type)<br>- Anti positivist<br>    - Karl Popper – 2 types of disciplines – pseudo science (theory is verifiable) and science (falsifiable)<br>        - Eg – suicide theory is verifiable but not fasifiable as solidarity makes sense but not falsifiable<br>    - Thomas Kuhn – young science and mature science; socio is a young science as multiple and single paradigm<br>        - Truth Is relative and based on the dominant paradigm<br>        - Eg – capitalism Marx vs Weber<br>    - Ethno and pheno – social world is illusion<br>    - Horkheimer – conservative and status quoist<br>    - Peter berger – “sociology of everyday life” – humans are not puppets who react blindly to external stimulus but create their own reality + social facts don’t fall from the sky but develop in a particular context<br>    - study in many ways -> Merton with his mid range theories<br>- Sayer – socio may have predictions which are not always valid but it doesn’t mean its not science, it is as much science as seismology ; open science<br>- In concl, socio in its nascent stage was ambitious to gain a scientific status, but later started studying science sociologically<br>- Non positivists<br>    - Interpretivists -> consider social world consisting of meanings and motivations of individuals<br>        - Study the social action of individual (SA – any action which is meaningly and intentional in a social context)<br>        - Collect qualitative data, meaning and motivations<br>        - Eg – intention behind divorce , experience of prosperity and poverty<br>        - Value neutrality should be maintained<br>        - Data collection by verstehen<br>        - Multi causality – no single phenomena but understand causal probabilism (one necessary cause but other sufficient causes)<br>    - Phenomenology –branch of interpretivist sociology which considers social world and the knowledge about it, as a social construction ie. social world consists of subjective experiences and meanings of individuals<br>        - Influenced by Weber’s theory of attaching meanings at a micro level- where meanings don’t have independent existence but reconstucted by actor in their social interactions<br>        - Tries to explain what role human awareness plays in social actions. The focus is to explain the meaning of phenomena instead of how they came in to existence<br>        - Meanings are not fixed and hence there cant be an objective fact<br>        - Every meaning depends on context (called indexicality)<br>        - Human beings attach meaning to phenomena in not a mental action but based on some “typifications (good bad, moral immoral) and depends on culture which finally creates social reality -> no objective idea ( Alfred Shutz in his phenomenology of the social world)<br>            - This was in contrast to Edmund Husserl who claimed classification of phenoema was a purely product of human mind<br>        - Purely qualitative data collected to understand diff objects, events, inst, object etc<br>        - Despite each ind having diff world view and meanings, social world/ order exists only because all of us have commonly agreed over few things<br>        - Eg marriage in Bihar (pakadhwa) vs church wedding in US<br>        - But even social order commonly agreed between members is also an illusion and not objective facts<br>        - Bracketing is a methodological tool used in phenomenology.<br>        - eg – data on crime , poverty (poverty rates diff by diff committees), exports -> opinion of investigator and not objective<br>        - questions even official data eg – GDP change base year<br>        - _P is required to explicate (explain) the concept which positivists take as granted in order to measure them (Hussrel)_<br>        - Eg – Cicourel’s study of juvenile justice ; police and juvenile officers had the problem of classifying the behaviour of juveniles into the categories: delinquent and non-delinquent. Cicourel did not find this process to be objective: it largely depended on the stereotypes of the ‘typical delinquent’ held by the official<br>        - Criticism – questions v existence of socio + too susbjective and common sensical<br><br>Extra<br><br>- - - Peter Berger and Thomas Luckmann – no reality other than subjective reality of individuals<br>        - Gabrielle Farina in her “Some reflections on the phenomological method” – it is nether a docrine nor a philosophical school but a style of thought where investigator can have different experiences and results each time<br>        - Create theories<br>        - Enhance research methods<br>        - Shutz: positivism not considered with socio but made out of socio<br>    - Ethno – Harold Garnfienkel – study from people perspective and not investigator perspective using a documentary<br>        - Phenological research to explain how members create order in society<br>        - There are socially constructed rules of everyday interaction.<br>        - Members of society are repeatedly performing these rules and maintain social order (Document of Rules)<br>        - But the social order is an illusion<br>        - Garfinkel introduced “Breaching experiment” to prove illusion -> disrupt the social order and record the reaction of members<br>        - On recording the reaction of members, it is found members become desperate to restore the original social order, which shows that social order is not naturally out there but a construction of the members following the rules of everyday interaction<br>        - Lodger experiment – ask mom for food bill<br>        - Focus on what people do instead of what people think as in P<br>        - Critique – labelled as traditional or folk methodology<br>        - Alvin Gouldner – E focused on trivial aspects of life which everyone is aware of<br>    - Symbolic interactionism – GH Mead and Herbert Blumer<br>        - Philosophy that explains social world as a set of symbols exchanged between members<br>            - Humans are endowed with cognitive thought/ cognition<br>            - Cognitive though is developed through social interaction<br>            - Social interaction involves exchange of signs, symbols, gestures<br>            - Meanings behind everything are created and shared through language<br>            - Social order is possible only because of exchange of symbols and mutually agreed meaning of symbols<br>            - Eg – unfurling flag or burning flag<br>    - Dramaturgy – by Goffman – philosophy which explains socio world is a theatre and members are performers<br>        - Each member performs a role in everyday life<br>        - Role is performed acc to status<br>        - Role performance is done in front stage<br>        - Members prepare for role keeping expectation of audience<br>        - Member is ideal in back stage<br>        - Every member resort to role distance is to be taken seriously in some context (sometimes become informal – off script)<br>        - Every member is doing impression mgt<br>        - Eg – Delta airlines -> air hostess offers service + smile (emotional labour concept)<br>- Post positivism<br>    - Philosophy which critiques and refines positivism -> doesn’t reject<br>    - Quanti + quali data -> eg – unemployment rate plus experience<br>    - Researcher has some value as they are also humans<br>    - Quantitative method of research eg survey + qualitiatve method such as interview (esp unstructured)<br>    - Triangulation method<br>    - Karl Popper + Thomas Kuhn | Critical theory/ conflict theory                                                                                                                           | - Branch of socio that considers society not a natural state but a social construct created by the dominant group (patterns of inequality created by few dominant groups)<br>- will collect data to expose anomalies in society and advocate change in society<br>- quanti data but quali change eg Ambedkar<br>- 2 groups – Marxists and feminists<br>- Marxists – economy is the basic structure -> social world characterized by eco infra defines social superstructure<br>    - Base of eco changes due to changes in production – means and tech; few groups command ownership as tech changes and masses work for those few<br>- Eg – Harvey and his study on exploitative role of social objects<br>    - Ken Plummer – study of transsexualism -> need for equality<br>- DEPENDENCY, SUBALTERN, MARXISTS, FEMINISTS<br>- Any research done by/ for/ of women. Focus on gender inequality but also advocate change through policy formulation or activism<br>- Features<br>    - Preference to women experience about their working or domestic life<br>    - Pref to qualitative data like unstructured interview, case study, etc<br>    - Preference to building rapport with research subject eg Ann Oakley studied experience of women in transition to motherhood<br>    - Time taking process<br>    - Advocates inter sectionality (eg Dalit women most exploited); black/ muslim/ dalit or combination of each<br>    - Kimberley Crenshaw – developed the intersectionality approach<br>    - Aim to create social change either by movement, policy advocacy or reforms at intl level<br>    - Mainstream is male stream research -> aim to de-masculinise and feminize malestream research<br>    - Eg – Ann Oakley conducted detailed study on women experience to motherhood using qualitative research method like unstructured interview<br>    - Eg – Claudia Goldin –<br><br>Features of Critical social research:<br><br>1. Abstract concepts and ideology: Critical social research use abstract concepts such as housework, but<br><br>goes beyond simply carrying out empirical studies based on such concepts.<br><br>o Critical research tries to get beneath the surface of social reality. Distorted ideological beliefs may<br><br>be related to dominant classes or to patriarchal or racist beliefs.<br><br>o They mask the material reality that lies behind these beliefs. But critical social research involves<br><br>trying to overcome the dominant ideology or ideologies.<br><br>2. Totality, structure and history: Each abstract concept and particular belief cannot be examined in<br><br>isolation. According to Harvey it is necessary to relate each bit of a society to a totality.<br><br>o Harvey says: Totality refers to the view that social phenomena are interrelated and form a total<br><br>whole.<br><br>o Critical social scientists see societies as possessing structures. Structures constrain or limit what<br><br>people can do, but also make social actions possible. Structures, though, are not static; they<br><br>change.<br><br>o Studies of society therefore need to be related to particular historical contexts. One needs to<br><br>examine how particular societies have changed over time in order to understand them at any<br><br>particular point in time.<br><br>3. Deconstruction, essence and reconstruction: Critical social researchers proceed through a process of<br><br>deconstruction and reconstruction.<br><br>o In the process of deconstruction, the different elements of particular areas of social life are taken<br><br>apart in order to try to discover an essence. The essence is the 'fundamental concept that can be<br><br>used as the key to unlocking the deconstructive process'.<br><br>o Reconceptualization - thinking of familiar aspects of social life in unfamiliar ways - is the key to<br><br>discovering essences through deconstruction. This process is never finished. The process of<br><br>deconstruction does not follow a pre-set path, as laid down by, for example, positivists.<br><br>o Deconstruction leads to reconstruction. The researcher aims in the end to 'lay bare the essential<br><br>relationships that are embedded in the structure'. They develop theoretical insights that allow the<br><br>phenomena under investigation to be seen in a new way.<br><br>4. Praxis: Critical social research is not just a theoretical activity; it is also a form of praxis.<br><br>o Harvey defines praxis as 'practical reflective activity. Praxis does not include "instinctive" or<br><br>"mindless" activity like sleeping, breathing, walking, and so on, or undertaking repetitive work<br><br>tasks. Praxis is what changes the world.".<br><br>- For Marxists, subject matter is peasants, poor, vulnerable, marginalized | Objectivity                                                                                                                                                | - Quality of researcher to keep investigation free from bias, opinion and personal value/ prejudice, value and subjective interpretation<br>- Borrowed from natural sciences and Was colonized by positivists for the longest time i.e quantitative data as the symbol of good research<br>- However weber questioned in his book “Objectivity in social sciences” and redefined objectivity in his work<br>    - Value neutrality: Collect Qualitative data in a value neutral manner<br>    - Vale relevance: every researcher is opinionated and hence should declare his/ her values right at onset of research (tell why)<br>    - Causal probabilism: multiple causes but necessary sufficient eg protestant<br>    - Ideal type : no absolutely objective scientific analysis of social phenomena independent of one sided view points. Every researcher has one sided understanding of social world which only explains his model of world. He should clearly state that he is only studying model of the world<br>- Robert Bierstedt – defines objectivity as conclusions derived from investigation are independent of race, caste, colour, nationality and political predisposition of investigator<br>- Multiple sources of subjectivity incl<br>    - Choice of topic and problem definition . weber argues subjectivity can be tolderated at this level in his book “MOSS”<br>    - Question to be answered in research<br>    - Research methodology deployed by investigator<br>    - Interpretation of the investigation data analysis – Oscar lewis and Robert Redfield in Tepostaton both observed Mexico – RR functional approach and harmony; Marxist approach and conflict<br>    - Subjectivity in certain research methodologies and empirical data collection itself like qualitative interviews, participant observation and non participation observation (prejudice) eg – feminists suggest supporting the interviewee<br>    - CHOICE OF testing tools<br>    - Challenges in data collection – Andre Beteille not allowed in Sripuram village<br>        - William Whyte – from non participant observer to participant non observer<br><br>Has been explained by multiple thinkers incl<br><br>- Max Weber in his – value free research via ideal types<br>- Durkheim in his “Rules of sociological method” – consider social facts as things<br>- Other safegurads<br>    - Clearly lay down bias<br>    - Use spatial and temporal dimensions<br>    - Focus on testing and reflexivity<br>    - Double blind in research<br>    - Larger sample<br>    - Temporal and wider applicability research<br><br>Difficiult to achieve objectivity as<br><br>- Dilthey – a fact based approach focuses on one dimension and ignores other cultural ideological dimensions<br>- Phenomenologists like Shutz – subject matter has consciousness and Hussrel – socio research can not be value free<br>- Gunnar Myrdal - - total objectivity is an illusion which can never be achieved<br>- Also, lose reformist agenda<br>- Alvin gouldner – Value neutrality is an elusive goal in sociology as investigators have to deal with multiple layer truth<br><br>Hence desirable yet elusive goal with its own limitations due to the unique subject matter of socio which possesses consciousness . deploy most objective research methods for meaningful results | Types of research methods                                                                                                                                  | Theories make hypothetical claims and data helps in supporting, disproving or modifying them<br><br>_Definitions_<br><br>Methodology<br><br>- Research methodology refers to the theoretical and philosophical framework that guides the entire research process<br>- the principles, concepts, approaches used to conduct research, including the overall strategy, and justification for choosing research methods<br><br>Types of data – primary and secondary<br><br>- Primary – data collected by the investigator eg interview<br>- Secondary – data already available in some form and collected by others eg official statistics, reports<br>- Data analysis – organizing data in a systematic way to discover the pattern revealed<br>- Serendipity – accidently discover sth while other research (like a latent function -> eg Hawthorne effect – find impact of lighting but ended up finding productivity same as they knew they were being observed. unemployment at single and global level, but it manifests into reducing education spending!)<br><br>Quanti and qualti<br><br>- Every theory produces a claim which is either accepted or rejected<br>- Eg – suicide rate and industrialization – so need a comparative method to compare suicide rates before and after<br>- Overall we used 2 quanti methods 1. Official statistics and 2. Comparative method (statistics means method in socio and not data)<br><br>\|   \|   \|<br>\|---\|---\|<br>\|quantitative research **method**\|Quali\|<br>\|Positivist **methodology**\|Interpretivist\|<br>\|Quanti data\|Quali data\|<br>\|Survey, official stats\|In depth interview, observation\|<br>\|Used for Generalizations in social world eg – poverty pattern, suicidebsolidarity\|Used for find experiences or world view of limited number of individuals or groups in detail ; usually not generalizable\|<br>\|Benefit – pulse check (official stats), verifiable , explanatory , unemployment as a root cause of poverty\|Eg – Weber’s idea of verstehen and ideal types<br><br>Eg – Ann Oakley research on Housewives<br><br>Eg Robert merton reference group theory<br><br>Ef stouffer’s soldier deprivation theory<br><br>Eg – cicourel theory of delinquent behavior\|<br><br>Epistemological foundation of research method<br><br>- Branch which deals with sources of knowledge - process of knowing the social world<br>- 3 ways – direct observational (positivist), indirect experienced (interpretivist), critically examined (critical)<br>- Socio knowledge not same as philosophical or personal belief. Since socio claims to be a scientific discipline, it relies on empirical data. Both quantu and quali data in studies are empirical in nature.<br>- There are 3 major approaches to know about social world empirically – positivist, inter and critical<br><br>Feminist and Marxist researches<br><br>Types of quanti research method<br><br>- Sociologists use data ie convert social world into a numerical data eg suicide rate, poverty rate, workforce participation raye eyc<br>- Structured interview<br>- Official statistics – stats published by govt – can be hard facts (cannot be fiddled with) or soft facts (eg crime rate- can be fiddled)<br>    - Phenomenologist critical as data shows more of their priotities in collection rather than the people surveyed<br>- Survey -><br>    - Method in which multiple individuals respond to series of questions on a questionnaire or an interview selected from a target population<br>    - It may take the form of a questionnaire or interview<br>    - looks at large-scale social patterns abd make comparable resuls<br>    - It can be quali or quanti<br>    - Features<br>        - Runs on Q given to sample of respondents eg – pollsters use survey to gauge public opinion<br>        - Manufacturers use it to understand product feedback<br>    - Looks at large scale social patterns<br>    - Can be open ended or close ended questions<br>    - Ques may be based on likert gutman or Bogardus scale<br>- Questionnaire -> a series of written questions which a researcher presents to respondents<br>    - Post/ email/ hand<br>    - Consists of 2 kinds of ques -> Close ended or open ended (veg/non veg or why)<br>    - Q used by feminist researcher, Marxists, economists, psychologists to understand or collect response on inequality/ gender/ caste race<br>    - It can be used to find answer to v specific questions<br>    - Can be used as a component of a large scale social survey in an otherwise spatially dispersed sample as well<br>    - Used by Karl Marx – first time survey in 1880s composed 101 questioned survey titled “Worker’s enquiry” amongst more than 25k French workers to understand nature of exploitation<br>    - Have high reliability as standardized<br>    - Have high validity as qualitative data can be collected<br>    - Used by Goldthorpe in his affluent worker study<br>- Lab experiment – written notes<br>- Scale approach -> used to collect quanti data from a set of population (sample)<br>    - Likert scale – 1,2,3,4,5 eg swiggy; not so reliable<br>    - Guttman scale – consisting of less likely, most, most unlikely/ agre, strongly agree<br>    - Bogardus social distance scale - experience of living with minorities in US -> used to measure ipiion of a group about another group (how likely are yoigoing to stay with minority); can have both likerd and gutman<br>    - ![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 16.png>)Helps in quantifying qualitative questions + standardization data collection<br>    - Easier to analyze and draw conslusions<br>    - Efficiency an reducer error<br>    - Economical and efficient<br>- Structured interview/ formal interview<br>    - A structured interview is a series of questions a researcher asks respondents in person.<br>    - Mainl closed questions<br>    - Asme ques in same order comparable results<br>    - Respondent can chose only from given options<br>- Laboratory experiment/controlled experiment: experiment that takes place in a closed environment where researcher creates laboratory like condition, creates groups like experiment group and controlled group, observe the impact of independent variable on the experiment group (dependent variable).<br>    - - Bandura’s bobo doll experiment was conducted to study whether violent television LEADS TO more violence in kids – ans yes; so correlation or causation<br><br>Quali research methods<br><br>- Work with non numerical data for understanding social world and theories like text, notes, videos<br>- They describe lived experience in detail<br>- Eg – experience of youth going to clg<br>- Unstructured interviews<br>    - Eg Arlie Hochschild – 50 couples in a 2 career marriage and 45 otherwise to understanding how shared responsibilities in nwew reality called “the second shift”<br>- Ethnography/ participant observation -><br>    - PO is a subset of a Ethno -> PO is a technique of data collection whereas ethno is a research method<br>    - Technique where researcher immerses himself in native’s everyday life and study their culture – PO<br>        - Eg – MNS multi caste tribal groups in Rampura – had diary + language -> identified a caste of people who were dominant caste who were shudras<br>            - Explained how untouchables were not allowed to sanskritize<br>        - Limitations – gatekeepers – insiders restrict your worldview to their world view<br>        - not allow data collection<br>        - location comfort<br>        - language learning – diff interpretation leads to reliability and validity<br>        - ethics of research<br>        - going native phenomena – you become that person<br>        - hawthorne effect<br>        - time consuming<br>        - no generalization<br>        - lower validaity<br>        - partial representation of reality – value relevance<br>        - problem of role allocation<br>    - SC Dube also – Sharmipet - method of conducting village study<br>    - PO has field work; E not necessary<br>    - E:<br>        - Method which involves deep engagement with community/ village/ tribe/ group in its natural setting eg MNS in Sripuram<br>        - Involves researcher building rapport with research subjects<br>        - Involves researcher learning local dialect/ lingo/ dialect<br>        - Maintains a dairy on inhabitants to keep data in a chronological manner<br>        - It helps in learning the “others” and their world view – develop subaltern perspective, feminist<br>        - Involves months to years to complete research<br>        - Eg – MNS on Coorg, or Brahmins in Sripuram<br>- FGD:<br>    - Involves a GD on a specific topic by the members from similar background<br>    - Participants are free to talk with other group members<br>    - Discussion is observed by researcher<br>    - Helps find solutions to problems to investigate group attitude and develop in depth understanding<br>    - Eg – new product and its features by cnsumers<br>    - Eg – discssion on social issue like climate change<br>    - From Robert Merton<br>- Grounded theory<br>    - developed by two sociologists Barney Glaser & Anselm Strauss<br>    - qualitative data based on data collected – create theory<br>    - based on this, create theory and refine more using further qualitative research<br>    - eg – how do you cope with stress – many interviews – seek social support – what kind – best way to manage stress is informal support<br>    - don’t start with a preconceived notion or a theory<br>- Comparative approach/ method<br>    - Compares variables within or across time or space<br>    - Typologies (Durkheim) -><br>        - 2 diff social groups within same society eg married single/ religious athiest<br>        - 2 diff social groups in 2 diff time scales eg Merton’s study before and after 40s<br>        - 2 diff societies in same time scale and across time scale -> karl marx comparison of diff counties or Europe at start of modern time and later<br>        - Develop generalization – Weber protestant ethics vs religion of India<br>- Biography<br>    - Voice of leaders or voice of mintority in main stream text<br>    - Study of individual life in depth to gather data and understanding about the person and historical context<br>    - Bios search as research method because it acts like primary source to collect data on the person in the form of photo, diary, letter, blog etc<br>    - It can help understand political ideology of leader through speeches and official docs<br>    - It can help give vice to minority groups<br>    - It can help to reveal intention and motivation of leaders and how they experienced any specific event<br>    - Eg – Diary of Benjamin Franklin (marx weber for study of Calvinists) and Ann Oakley (housewife study – own study and took their diary also – diary record of how they felt everyday for being responsible for household or childcare)<br>- Historical method<br>    - takes a theme and traces its evolution over time through the study of books, media reports, films, and historical accounts. Such studies require extensive use of secondary data gathered over long periods of time<br>    - eg – weber and mrx, caste evolution<br>    - data may not be precise/ available/ reliable/ accuracy<br><br>Data analysis significance<br><br>- Marketing and advertising<br>- Political campaign<br>- Analyze pop priorities eg >36 like gardening whereas 21-25 like clubs<br><br>Ray Pawson – debate on this 60s hangover<br><br>Alan Bryman | Sampling                                                                                                                                                   | - It is a process of collecting sample from pop for a desired research<br>- Random or non random sampling -><br>    - Random sample<br>        - Simple random – a process where everyone has equal chance of getting selected as a part of sample,. Done through random number generator eg – chits in a class<br>        - Stratified random – process of dividing the group into strata seg gender/ age based and then conducting random sampling within each strata<br>        - Systematic random – select every nth element as starting point and other members are selected after a fixed sampling interval<br>    - Non random<br>        - Convenience: those who are conveniently available to researcher are taken eg – first 30 customers of store<br>        - Voluntary response: a sample based on the ease of respondents. R directly contact the researchers and volunteer themselves<br>        - Purposive: Involves researcher using his/ her judgement to select a sample which is most useful to the purpose of research. Researcher wants to gain detailed knowledge about the specific group and may exclude other groups.<br>        - Snowball: It is used in cases which involves inaccessible or elite strata of society. Researcher gets in touch with a group and that group introduces researcher to another group | Research design                                                                                                                                            | - Refers to a set of/ document which lays down research question, objectives, sampling method and type of research method used for data collection<br>- Types<br>    - Exploratory: involves research to understand an unexplored phenomena eg – reason for certain dropout in school , why is suicide increasing<br>    - Explanatory : after understanding cause, researcher expalains cause in detail. Focus is on explaining a phenomena to cause effect relationship. Comes after exploratory research and aims to go deeper into result produced during exploratory research eg – what is impact (quali)<br>    - Descriptive: type of research which provides description of the characteristics of a phenomena eg – how many impacted – more quanti<br>- Utility<br>    - Limit scope<br>    - Conduct research comprehensively in a specific direction<br>    - Address dd of question<br>    - Decide research method<br>    - Imparts scientific status to research<br>    - Cross sectional research design – findings across time and space<br>    - Longitudinal research design<br>    - All based on question being studied<br>    - Value neutrality and objectivity<br>- No research without design | Hypothesis                                                                                                                                                 | - GA Lundberg - Tentative generalization whose validity yet remains to be tested<br>- usually links two or more social variables<br>- 2 – simple hypothesis, more than 2 – complex hypothesis<br>- eg<br>- acts as starting point for research eg – poverty as a factor behind crime rate<br>- helps in data collection,<br>- direction – quali or quanti (data method and research design)<br>- limit scope<br>- proving or disproving a claim<br>- making theory, generalization or law<br>- reliability and validity<br><br>Sources<br><br>- existing literature<br>- personal experience<br>- deductive theory uses hypothesis – positivists<br><br>Variables<br><br>- any data which is subject to change is a variable<br>- can be dependent or independent variable (effect and cause respectively)<br>- can be quanti (data on income, age poverty) or quali variable (data on experience)<br>- operationalization of variable -> process of quantifying a seemingly immeasurable phenomena eg – health of democract based on free |                                                                                                                                                            | - Triangulation is defined as the mixing of data or methods so that diverse viewpoints or standpoints cast<br>- light upon a topic. The mixing of data types, known as data triangulation, is often thought to help in<br>- validating the claims that might arise from an initial pilot study.<br>- It is a valuable strategy in social sciences to enhance the credibility, reliability, and comprehensiveness of<br>- research findings as given below:<br>- • Gain a more complete understanding: Employing a variety of research methods (qualitative,<br>- quantitative, and others) provides researchers with different perspectives on the same social<br>- phenomenon. For example, Lenin used a mixture of quantitative data tables along with a political economy<br>- analysis of charged words used in his classic research monograph, The Development of Capitalism<br>- in Russia (1898).<br>- • Minimize Bias: Each method has its own strengths and weaknesses. Triangulation allows researchers<br>- to leverage the strengths of different methodologies and mitigate the potential biases inherent in any<br>- single approach.<br>- o For instance, in “Distinction: A Social Critique of the Judgment of Taste,” Pierre Bourdieu<br>- integrated qualitative methods with quantitative analysis to mitigate biases inherent in singular<br>- methods.<br>- • Increased confidence in findings: Replication of results across different methods strengthens the<br>- reliability of findings. If various approaches consistently yield similar conclusions, it increases<br>- confidence that the findings are not simply an artefact of the chosen method.<br>- • Richer and more nuanced understanding: Triangulation allows researchers to capture a more<br>- complete picture of the social phenomenon under study. | Karl Marx                                                                                                                                                  | _Marx is an institution, not a person_<br><br>St simon – ethical socialism<br><br>_Historical Materialism: theory given by Marx how history evolves in dialectical manner through change in material condition_<br><br>- Book: Preface to **Contribution to Critique of Political Economy**<br>- What: Evolution of society (modes of production) with changes in material factors or economic infrastructure (consisting of forces of production and relations of production – relation b/w man and man and man and things)<br>- Supplemented by **dialectic materialism** where two opposing forces interact with each other and create new structures<br>    - Dialectics is a way of analysing society through study of inherent contradictions and negations<br>    - MOP – how soc s org for goods and services<br>    - Inspired by **Hegel’s idea** of Dialectical idealism (that society changes with new ideas – human mind is mother of everything) – I think therefore I exist<br>        - Hegel in his idealism focused on **dialectic approach** of **thesis, anti-thesis and synthesis** for change in society – ideas emerge, counter emerges and new ideas form<br>        - Hegel said society is evolving and has 3 stages – universal reflexivity (everyone has same ideas – same as mechanical solidarity of Durkheim); universal egoism (everyone is focused on self interest) and universal altruism (state exists)<br>        - Phenomenology of mind – book<br>        - Consciousness lies in ideas<br><br>\|   \|   \|<br>\|---\|---\|<br>\|- - - History evolves due to evolution of ideas\|- - - Due to material changes\|<br>\|- - - History evolved until absolute idea is reached\|- - - Until material conditions are reached\|<br>\|- - - Evolution due to dialectics between ideas\|- - - Dialectics between eco classes\|<br>\|- - - Ideas are primary, material secondary\|- - - Material primary, ideas secondary\|<br>\|- - - Creation of cosmic plan\|- - - Creation of ruling class\|<br>\|Material conditions<br><br>![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 18.png>)<br><br>ideas\|- - - ideas and superstructure by bourgeoise<br><br>![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 19.png>)<br><br>material conditions\|<br><br>- - But found this abstract, so took **Feuerbach’s** idea of materialism (society doesn’t change only with ideas)<br>    - Even considered Engel’s 3 laws of unity/ conflict of opposition, transition from quant to qual, negation of negation<br>    - Two opposing forces when interact with each other lead to conflict and create a new social structure<br>    - Talk about the MOP and “contradiction of history will end”<br><br>Salient features<br><br>1. Ideas are creation of ruling class<br>2. Economy is the case<br>3. Human is a working being<br><br>_Relations of production_<br><br>- **History is a process of man’s self creation**<br>- **In order to survive, man must produce**<br>- **Production is the first historical act**<br>- **Man is perpetually a dissatisfied animal**<br>- Humans have basic needs (roti kapda makaan) but they are not readily available. So individuals enter into social relations of production<br>- These relations help transform RM into finished goods using means of production (forces of production) eg – energy, tool tech etc<br>- Means of production are owned by a class of people<br>- Eventually, ownership justified with help of social structure created by ruling class (like religion)<br>- Due to inherent contradiction in economic system, class struggle develops. Old collapses and new comes in<br>- Class struggle is the motor of history<br>- Relation bw have (who own means of production) and have nots (who don’t own means of production)<br>- Forces of production keep changing with change in tech – instruments without which prod is not possible – consists of scientific knowledge, technological equipment and organization of collective labor<br>- Source of surplus lays in the excess of what bourgeoise / capitalist pay for labor power (ie the capacity to do value things which increases the value of the product) over the value labor power adds to a commodity<br>- These can be ownership (ownership remains with the bourgeoisie) or control relations (controls production process and labour)<br>- These man to man relations lead to **stratification based on their position in the production process**<br>- Relation is usually in the form of **antagonistic cooperation** for man-to-man<br>- Have nots don’t have ownership over things required in production process other than their own labour (not even that in ancient slave society)<br><br>![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 20.png>)<br><br>Relevance to way society is organized to create goods and services_<br><br>- Consists of means and relations of production (leads to have and have nots)<br>    - Tools used to create goods and services<br>- Relation between class who are producing goods and services<br>- Each MOP collapses due to inherent contradiction/ dialectics and from the other develops the new MOP<br>    - **Primitive communism**: collective ownership, production, distribution. over time, new needs develop leading to a new MOP due to inherent contradiction<br>        - all men were equal with equal access to forces of production in a “hunter gatherer society”. Food was abundant with ltd pop leading to cooperation rather than domination. But with invention of tools, society started breaking up as some men had more food than others, leading to private ownership with a few people and dependent slaves and hence a new mode of production emerged. negation of primitive communism<br><br>![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 21.png>)<br><br>- - **Ancient slave mode of production**: ownership – master, production by slave, distribution – unequal; secondary needs develop over time -> new MOP; now exploitation by masters sch as slave trade and plantation economy leads to **inherent contradictions** and ends in slave revolt<br>    - **Feudal mode of production**: inherent contradictions: internal (**reducing productivity, tax revenue systems**) and external (**emergence of mercantilism, enclosure movement** as well as people finding working opp in city life with rise of capitalists)<br>    - **Capitalism**: inherent contradiction –<br><br>1. **profit motive** leads to **overproduction of goods**<br>2. goods for profit and not to serve human needs (**commodity fetishism**)<br>3. wage cuts/ machines -> will create a **reserve army** of people<br>4. reduced purchasing power and over production -> **recession**<br>5. with recession, small and medium enterprises may lose market share and may be bought outby big players -> **monopolization**<br>6. now lower middle class will join **proletariat class (proletarianization**) and upper middle class will in bourgeoise (**monopolization**)<br>7. homogenization of Working class with more technological innovation<br>8. pauperization increases + depression of middle class (movement)<br>9. capitalism will be overthrown<br>    - - **Exchange value more than use value -> commodities are created**<br>        - Difference between subsistence wages paid to labour and overall production is surplus which goes to capitalist. Such private ownership of surplus will lead to class struggle by workers, who will start feeling alienated and will demand ownership of surplus (Negation of negation)<br>        - **Features – money as a medium of exchange, ownership of capital with the bourgeoise, production process controlled by the capitalist, financial decision by the capitalist, commodity fetishism – goods for sale rather than own consumption**<br>    - **Socialism**: Proletariat will assume ownership of the means of production and production process in response to the class conflict of capitalism. There will be no private property – “disctatorship of class”.<br>    - **And surplus will be discutributed Communism**: “**Contradiction of history will end**” – Proletariat will renounce ownership of production process and truly end class conflict, where everyone will be equal. No new unequal relations of production, which ends dialectical materialism. Forces of production are collectively owned<br>    - **In conclusion, MOP develops in response to seeds of dialectics in previous MOP**<br>    - **Critical**<br>        - Dialectics between sexes ignored eg women suffrage movement<br>        - Dialectics of caste ignored eg Ambedkar<br>        - Class collaboration – trade union, cooperatives, labor codes, ESOPs<br><br>Reserve army<br><br>- Consists of unemployed, partially employed or under employed individuals<br>- Expands with conditions of recession<br>- Typology<br>    - Floating: workers regularly displaced due to cyclical fluctuations, bankruptcy, failure of firms and tech innovations<br>    - Stagnant: workers whose employment is seasonal or irregular<br>    - Latent: workers displaced from agri due to capitalist dev -> Changes in ASS show MOP evolution as per AR Desai<br>    - Excessive limitation on creativity leads to alienation<br>- **Man’s consciousness doesn’t decide his being, contrary, social relation determine his consciousness**<br><br>Alienation (**economic and political manuscripts**)<br><br>- In capitalist MOP, alienation reaches its peak as **labour is only a means to end, which is production for capitalis**t. He becomes a slave in production and creativity is lost<br>- Hence, he starts getting **separated, isolated and powerless and meaningless** when he confronts social institutions that they cant control and consider oppressive<br>- He gets a feeling a **estrangement and disenchantment** from a group, others even oneself<br>- Alienation happens in two ways: in a given MOP, it increases with time as exploitation increases + degree increases as MOP increases<br>- 4 types of alienation<br><br>Alienation of proletariat<br><br>- - Process: Process is fixed irrespective of his own individuality and he doesn’t have any control over production process. Work becomes a means to end. The extreme DOL coerces him to become a part of the work and mechanical work does not satisfy him<br>    - Product: cant determine the fate of what he produces. Market works to promote the interest of the capitalist and not the worker. doesn’t have control over quality or quantity of product<br>    - Peers: isolated and compartmentalized work with no time to interact with others. Also competes for scarce jobs<br>    - Self: he loses control over his own thoughts also and works out of compulsion and not choice<br>- End is de-alienation which will involve capitalism where forces are collectively owned + condition of work is humanized<br>- **It is possible for me to do one thing to do and another tomorrow**<br>- **It was a history of man’s increasing control over nature, at the same time it was history of increasing alienation of man**<br>- **Explains rising alienation and silent quitting**<br>- **Even alienation amongst bourgeoise as they produce what the market wants and not what they want**<br><br>**Supported by**<br><br>- **Weber – iron cage theory with extreme bureaucratization**<br>- CW Mills (White collar): even white collared people suffer alienation. | Weber (father of modern socio)                                                                                                                             | - Sociology is a science which attempts at **interpretive understanding of social actions** to arrive at explanation of cause and effect<br>- Bridged gap between positivism (use of scientific methods) and idealism (Kant<br><br>Social action<br><br>- First developed in “Economy and society”<br>- An action with a meaning attached by actor, oriented towards others and taking into account the behavior of others<br>    - Meaning attached: actor is conscious of his actions and has some motivation to take it. Values don’t have an independent impact on the actor but are interpreted by the actor to undertake action<br>    - Oriented towards others, which may be physically or mentally present.<br>- Understand cause and effect – basis of sociology<br>    - 4 types of **Ideal types** **of social action**<br>        - Rationality -> orientation to reality which weighs means and ends for purpose of efficacy<br>        - Affective – meaning is generated due to emotional response dedicated by the mind of the actor<br>        - Traditional – meaning due to cultural beliefs and traditions -> reacts automatically to habitual stimuli which guides in course of repetition or belief<br>        - zweck rational – action with logical means to achieve logical end -> by well calculated logic and plan<br>        - wert rational – value oriented rational actions - driven by value of society<br>        - eg – why actor (SRK/ Kapoor family/ bring social change/ earn a lot)<br>        - No action is a pure action. In reality, every action is muddled. So ideal type can help understand theoretical pure types not found in reality<br>- Weber rejected methods of natural science and developed his own methods in “Methodologies for Social Science”<br>- Verstehen (to interpret) – translate to human understanding (MOSS)<br>    - First by Dilthey but interpretivism by Weber and simmel<br>    - Foundation of most of Weber’s work and one of his key contributions<br>    - Human understanding which involves comprehending at the level of actor by following systematic simple steps<br>    - Investigator should reconstruct the actor’s situational choices and constraints<br>    - He should be at the same wavelength with the actor<br>    - He should have no sympathy to actor or situation; maintain objectivity in his investigation<br>    - He should interact with actor to get primary sources of data<br>    - This can maximise the probability to understand true meaning behind an social actions<br>    - Meaning can be drawn via two observations (Eco and soc): direct observation (where meaning is clearly visible and understand by physical characteristics of the act and the external world eg shouting) or explanatory observation (investigator draws meaning by explaining the situation and constraint – puts the act in a context and assigns a motive to it) eg – wood to sell or fire<br>    - Based on the idea that meaning precedes social act. Weber study of “meangingful conduct”<br>- Causal Pluralist method – rejected the mono-causal theory for social actions, and said there are multiple causes leading to a social action. Focus should be on identifying the probable causes (Probabilistic theory) to understand meaning of social actions.<br>- Ideal types: 2nd most important contribution by Weber, which involves developing abstractions to understand complexity of social world by focusing on certain traits of an item<br>    - one sided **mental category** which highlights features deemed essential by researcher<br>    - **It is not a description of reality in itself but a way to express reality – it is not a pure type**<br>    - **Lachman: Act as measuring rod to understand actual phenomenon. These are heuristic devices**<br>    - Weber agrees there are regularities in societies, but these regularities are in the mind of the actor. The actor has subjective interpretation of these regularities<br>    - Used for comparison, building hypothesis and **limited generalization**<br>    - Ideal type tries to understand meanings in term of **regularities** and differences<br>    - Helps in giving objectivity to research<br>    - **Ideal types are formed by a number of elements, which may or may not be directly observable and hence are identified by subjective understanding of the investigator**<br>        - They are neither description nor hypothesis of reality but can help in description or explanation<br>        - Often used to general phenomena that occur at diff times and places<br>        - Aim – look at society objectively without bias – nth to do with values<br>    - Ideal types can be used in 3 categories: Historical particular, Abstract phenomena (such as social action or authority), particular behaviour (such as economic/ pol behaviour of supply demand )<br>    - benefits<br>        - Gives a ready framework for investigators to understand meanings<br>        - saves time<br>        - helps in forecasting<br>        - establish linkages amongst distinct social phenomenas (such as Protestant ethics and capitalism)<br>    - Used in **Economic and social organization, city and sociology of religion**<br>    - **Susan jones – helped socio become a separate discipline**<br>    - **Criticism -> difficult to understand the true meaning without context + bias of investigator**<br>        - **Ignored latent meaning**<br>    - **Examples of ideal type today**<br>        - **Capitalism – std, free market, profit motive – but in reality, sate intervention**<br>        - **Democracy – equality, representation, no unfair practices (diff types across world)**<br>        - Family – middle class happy family (cereal family) – actual neolocal , diff features in diff families<br><br>Authority – essay 1922<br><br>- Power is an aspect of social relationships<br>- Power is chane to influence others even against their will/ resistance and regardless of the basis on which opportunity rests<br>- He elaborate his study in context of power in history of society what called “Herschaf – authority”<br>- **Chance or probability** of command being obeyed by **group of people** is authority<br>- Power has an element of coercion also, where authority is a form of legitimate power<br>- Elements of authority<br>    - Master/ ruler or a group of masters/ rulers<br>    - Ind/ group that is ruled<br>    - Will of ruler is expressed through commands<br>    - Evidence of influence of rulers in compliance<br>    - Direct/ indirect evidence that rulers commands need to be obeyed<br>- Patterns of authority have changed over time. 3 types of authority –<br>    - Traditional: authority **obeyed due to belief in traditions**, customs and values.<br>        - To make traditional authority more palatable, he made 3 ideal types within the ideal type<br>        - Gerontocracy – rule of elderly eg gram panchayat (no staff)<br>        - Patriarchalism eg fater, father in law, maternal uncle (no staff)<br>        - patrimonialism : elderly men with proper staff for administration (eg -Parliament)<br>    - Charismatic:<br>        - Authority obeyed due to belief in charisma of a person<br>        - Eg – religious, political, business (eg – steve jobs), edu (Divyakranti)<br>        - Defines as a certain quality of an individual by virtue of which he is considered **extraordinary** and treated as endowed with supernatural, superhuman or atleast specifically **exceptional** powers or qualities<br>        - from personal traits of the leader. | Talcott Parsons<br><br>VALUE CONSENSUS IN SOC MAINTAINED BY AGIL FRAMEWORK AND A PRE-REQUISITE FOR SURVIVAL OF SOCIETY<br><br>Neo structural functionalist | - Parsons analyzed and criticized the existing schools of thought as follows<br>    - Utilitarians – studied the social world in a highly individualistic fashion ; however they focus on individual choice and miss the collective<br>    - Positivists believed that laws of society can be observed as natural scines using empiricism and generalization ; they overlook the role of values and norms<br>    - Idealists – believed ideas/ consciousness is the basis of all social reality; they focus on values but miss out of external pressures of society<br>- Father of structural functionalism, esp in America with his grand functional theories, while considering micro aspect of social action<br>- He saw society as a social system comprising of sub systems with actors having unique functional pre-requisites<br>- Society evolves from easy to complex forms<br>- He rejected Hobbes view that man functions out of fear – instead he believed value consensus is the integrating force of society and motivates man to undertake roles<br>- Motive of socio is to understand how this value consensus is reached<br><br>Social action (Structure of social action)<br><br>- An act done consciously is social action. 4 elements<br>    - Act in a social situation<br>    - Orientation towards attainment of a goal<br>    - Regulated by norms and values<br>    - Investment of energy<br>- The orientation may be motivational (**cognitive** – see envt in relation to their need, **cathectic** – based on emotional attitude of the actor towards object, **evaluative** – evaluate the optimum efficiency) taking into account needs and plans or value orientation (**appreciative** – judge emotional response, **cognition** – judge validity of judgement, **moral** – what is the right thing to do)<br>    - Motivational arise due to personal condition of actor<br>    - Value orientation rises due to value and norms of society<br>- Three types of social action:<br>    - Instrumental (similar to Zweck rational social Action) – where evaluative motivation is dominating<br>    - Expressive – appreciative value component<br>    - Moral – value orientation is dominant – you are working according to societal norms<br><br>![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 30.png>)<br><br>- - Ideal type of classification of social action, modes of orientation and social system is pattern variable<br>    - Parsons categorically classified human actions and society to expressive orientation and instrumental orientation<br>    - Expressive orientation had emotional expression, personal relationships vs instrumental orientation involves prioritize individualism, achievement of goals and rules and fulfilment of responsibilities<br>    - 6 types of dichotomies possible ADAPCO<br>        - Affective vs affective neutrality – A is quality of expressing one’s emotions eg – at home or romantic relationship, need affectivity whereas no expressive emotion in workplace<br>        - Diffuseness vs specificity – D is a quality of multiple roles played by a single individual vs well defined roles by specialized individuals eg mother plays a diffused role whereas a teacher when only be a teacher in school<br>        - Ascription vs achievement<br>        - Particularism vs universality – P is giving preferential treatment to individuals on basis of expressive ties. Vs U is equal treatment to everyone irrespective of personal ties-> special privilege to a friend (individual as unique vs same – impartial and fair)<br>        - Collectivity vs self orientation : see himself as apart of bigger whole vs independent<br>        - Eg – In India no tradition to modernization but modernization of tradition eg – caste based political party, secularism of India<br>        - It is the affinity between mode or orientation and subsystem that define social order of society<br>        - Helps in<br>            - Understanding modern institutions eg education schools with achievement based and universal<br>            - Understand conflict between traditional and modern orientation eg caste based reservation and caste based meritocracy<br>            - Understand changing roles in family eg in family traditional roles like mother expressive, as feminization - > mother enters workforce – nuclear families<br>            - But Eurocentric based on binary – Asian as modernization of traditional insittuions<br>    - Tonnies also follows similar type of social system<br><br>Action system and Social system (Structure of social action and The Social system)<br><br>- Action systems don’t exist in real world but are tools to analyze the real world<br>- Social actions don’t happen in isolation but in constellations of social actions of individuals known as action systems. 4 Types of action systems<br>    - Culture system – consisting of beliefs, norms and values; “storehouse of information”; Inspired by **Malinowski**<br>    - Social system – actual interaction of various units in society. Institutionalized roles create social system<br>    - Personality system – internal and hidden aspect of society driven by motivations such as love, anger, tension sress alone; inspired by **Mead**<br>    - Organismic system : biological/ physical aspect of society; called the storehouse of energy<br>    - These are not real world but tools for analysing the real world<br>- Institutionalized social structure called social system<br>- Wanted to study how the norms and values of a system are transmitted to actors within the system<br>- Conditions for conception of a social system<br>    - There should be a social interaction between 2 or more individuals<br>    - For achievement of some collective goal<br>    - There is a consensus on role expectation<br>    - They develop an abstract boundary around them<br>- While each system maintains its boundaries and are distinct, Social system is linked to other system and influence each other through **knowledge flow and energy flow, which is called cybernetic hierarchy of control**<br>    - CHC is achieved by socialization and social control<br>    - Socialization is the transmission of valyes from one gen t another via school or fam<br>    - Social controls discourage deviance and various inst enforcing it are law/ police etc<br>- Social system consists of plurality of individual actors interacting with each other, in a situation which has an environment with actors who are motivated in terms a tendency to optimization of gratification<br>- Hence social system has a structure (units/ family/ kinship etc) and functions (performance leads to gratification and attainment of common goals)<br>- Functions/ characteristics of a social system include:<br>    - Social system should have a structure<br>    - Should be supported by other system<br>    - Should meet significant need of its members<br>    - Should have a language<br>    - Should have a system to affress any disruptive behaviour<br>- Developed structural functional theory in phases<br>    - Social equilibrium is the state of balance both internally amongst social phenomena and to external environment<br>    - Requisites functional phase (Social structure): Functions of AGIL framework need to be fulfilled for survival of any society/ structure<br>        - Adaptation (economic system): need for survival production of goods and services by controlling resources in envt. eg – father earning<br>            - Fulfilled by organismic system<br>        - Goal attainment: political system performs this function to define, energize, motivate, mobilise actors to achieve a common goal – determine the goal and achieve the goal<br>        - Integration: by social institution to maintain harmony and resolve conflict– coherence, solidarity and coordination in system<br>        - Latency: needs fulfilled by by cultural systems – need for socialization and cultural learnings eg- family, religion, school<br>    - However, certain factors cause strain in the system.<br>        - Eg – demographic issues eg – pop, migration, skewed sex ration<br>        - Tech issues – any tech like AI which can displace employees/ cause unemployment<br>        - New ideas like French revolution and enlighten, swaraj , Buddhism<br>        - Physical envt – CC, droughts<br>    - When soc experiences factors causing strain, society develops re-equilibriumating tendency. It means society evolves in a manner that it can deal effectively with a strain<br>    - In this process of adaptation, structural differentiation takes place<br>    - Eg – AI -> law update, edu update<br>    - Structural adaptation – organs of society re-align themselves to address issues at home<br>    - Structural differentiation – process of breakdown of roles of an institution and dev of specialized inst to deal with specific role eg -live ins and dating apps, banks, P2P lending, grants, surrogacy/ IVR, counselling<br>    - Mechanism equilibrium phase (SOSA): When specific mechanisms exist, and satisfy needs, there is an equilibrium. If there is a disruption, feedback is passed back to mechanism for a new equilibrium (this is what he called the moving equilibrium); eg - cybercrime<br>        - “feedback” from the action system to another. Eventually, these new inst will work towards maintaining eq (cybernetic web of control) – hence moving eq.<br>        - Tendency to restore eq in case disturbed because of any change in a social element<br>    - Status quoist – no explanation of dictator, rising inequality (Marxists)<br>    - Parsons believed after adaptation and diff, generalization of values is the automated process<br>    - Eg – edu changes -> we understand its part of system<br><br>- - change is restorative to bring back equilibrium<br>    - Supremacy of structure over individual in society<br>- ![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9
