| Merton (neo-functionalist)                                                                                                                                 | - Gave more practical theories vs functionalists (which are unworkable) and micro theoris (which have limited consequences)<br>- Disagreement to 3 postulates by structural theorists like Radliffe and Malinowski<br>    - Universal Functionalism :<br>        - Social reality needs to be seen in terms of a system<br>        - Structural functionalists believed that **different objects or phenomena** perform function of unity of system<br>        - But merton believed not all objects or social groups are functional and some may be dysfunctional/ non-functional, which do not contribute to unity of the system<br>        - Brown, Spencer, Durkenheim<br>        - Eg – nuclear weapons<br>        - Hence, look at macro and meso level – both societal and group level<br>    - Functional indispensability:<br>        - Brown and Parsons: Some functions are bound to performed by society and **social institutions/ social items** are indispensable for performing these functions<br>        - Eg – Parsons AGIL framework<br>        - Merton: functional alternatives exist and no institution is indispensable<br>        - They infact lead to social change<br>        - Eg – creches<br>        - Eg – caste discrimation is not indispensable<br>    - Functional unity<br>        - Social items are not always working for society as a whole but also for some social groups<br>        - Social and cultural forms / social items are functionable and create positive function for the society<br>        - Merton: need to be studied in the context of the social item<br>        - Eg – medicinal marijuana or abortion<br>- Contribution of merton<br>    - Need to look at net balance study of functionalism – function and dysfunction at both macro and meso levels of society<br>    - Added levels of society<br>    - Considered functional as status quoist<br>- Merton’s PoV: These functional theories are non-empirical and abstract. Empirical analysis is critical for functional analysis<br>- Also suggested a functional paradigm, a systematic approach, to conduct the functional analysis as he believed current functional theories were based on abstract non empirical works.<br>    - This was an integration of theirie with empirical data and research<br>    - Social item should be in a standardized pattern (not too abstract or too concrete)<br>    - Social context needs to be defined<br>    - General description of social item<br>    - Primary and secondary data should be used<br>    - Manifest functions identified<br>    - Latent functions identified<br>    - Dysfunctions identified<br><br>Middle range theory<br><br>- Acc to Merton, Parsons theory of functional structure was too abstract and didn’t encompass all system of concept. It just provided some general orientation as to what variables should be considered in research . hence it was premature and sterile<br>- “Parsons is trying to be Einstein of socio while socio has not even have a Kepler”<br>- Bridge between raw empiricism and grand theories<br>- Characteristics<br>    - Limited assumptions or generalizations which can be verified<br>    - Use concepts which can operationalize the gap between theory and empiricism<br>- Specific hypothesis followed by empirical evidence to make it concrete instead of grand theories or too specific micro theories<br>- The theories will become more reliable, valid, and rightly organized<br>- Triple alliance theory of theory, data, method<br>- Benefit: empiricism, credibility, testability, reproducibility, reduce time, reduce cost, targeted<br>- Disadvantage: Not specific on what constitutes middle?<br>    - Limited scope of framing universal theories<br>    - Subjectivity<br>    - Fragmentation of knowledge because limited social reality and only after extensive research totality<br>    - Raymond Bound – nth but what science uses in theory building<br><br>![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 32.png>)<br><br>Latent and Manifest functions<br><br>- Social Theory and Social Structure<br>- Earlier functionalists looked at only manifest functions, whereas his theory combined psychological and socio-cultural functions<br>- One is an actual intention of the actor (manifest function – intended, recognized, expected) while other is the unintended function from the action of the actor<br>    - Unintended has Latent function, latent dysfunction, no function<br>- Manifest function is analysed by micro theories, usually non-positivist<br>    - Parsons motivational approach/ inspired by Weber<br>    - Psychological dimension of sociological reality<br>- Latent functions often include dysfunctional or unanticipated functions. The actor is unaware and has impact on social structure. This may need both qualitative and quantitative analysis eg. Class and salve domination, dowry, social media isolation, GAI<br>- Hopi tribes and rain dance illustration (rain but actually integration )<br>- Dysfunctional items may have positive latent functions and negative manifest functions and vice versa<br>- Significance: combined positivist non positivist angles; increased scope of socio<br>- Veblen – used example of conspicuous spending on cars (travel and status)<br>- Differentiated between unintended consequences and latent functions, where LF are one type of unintended consequences (which also have latent dysfunction and no function or dysfunction of an action)<br>- Partial view of realiy<br>- Eg – work from home, reproduction, education,<br>- Critique<br>    - Critics said that when he talked about functional alternative, he really was talking about structural alternatives. Semantic criticism.<br>    - Critics said that his model failed to predict dysfunction causing circumstances.<br>    - A status quoist as with latent functions he had effectively legitimised everything.<br>    - Overemphasis on latent functions, may compromise manifest functions eg one child policy to control national reproduction<br>    - Difficult to identify latent functions eg – purchasing contributes to GDP, helps in capitalism – leads to alienation<br>- PYQ-> unintended consequence vs latent function – eg edu, climate, social media<br>- Eg – exam, select student, creates celebs, suicide rates go up, unemployment, rote learners<br>- Colin Campbell – it is difficult to have clear cut differentiation between latent and manifest; function and dysfunction<br><br>Conformity and Deviance<br><br>- Social Structure and Anomie<br>- Conformity: action with Orientation to social norms and expectations, and within tolerance prescription of society<br>- Deviation: action non-conformity with prescribed norms; reasons for deviation<br>    - Subculture<br>    - Parent deprivation<br>    - Faulty association<br>    - Differential opportunities<br>- Deviance is a result for anomie<br>- Deviation can be positive and rewards (Nobel) or negative and punished (such as crime)<br>- Anomie: Discrepancy between culturally defined goals and structurally available means to achieve them<br>- Gave the **structural strain theory** – individuals feel strain to achieve goals when they don’t have legitimate means to achieve them, which forces them to find alternatives and adopt deviant behaviour- lower class feels the strain more<br>- Eg – **American dream** to work in high end jobs needs education (structural means), which may not be available to all; leads to increased crimes from unemployment – feasibility of jounrye from log cabin to white house<br>- Developed in backdrop of great economic depression<br>- Different types of social actors based on their **adaptive responses**<br>    - Conformist: accepts the cultural goals and the means available to achieve them, irrespective of their utility or fairness (majority pop such as edu)<br>    - Innovator: accepts goal but not the means (scientists or thieves, smuggler)<br>    - Ritualist: accepts means but least concerned about the goal (red tapism, employees)<br>    - Rebellion: nether accepts goal nor means, but creates alternate means and goals eg social reformers – proponent of counter culture<br>    - Retreatist: doesn’t accept CULTURAL goals or legitimate means eg alcoholist<br>- What may be conformist at one time may be deviant for another time.<br>- Every conformist may be deviant at some time and vice versa<br>- Many cultures diverge from each other while defining conformity such as LGBTQ<br>- Even relevant for understanding traffic issues in India – need to reach on time so take illegitimate means – also confirmed by Giddens<br>- Goffman – we all are socially deviant<br>- Criticism theory<br>    - Howard Becker (Labelling theory reconsidered): labelling theory said a person is deviant labelled, not for another group but + he is not deviant, he is labelled deviant<br>    - Taylor and Lemert: People with power define deviance and not cultural norms; they mark them as deviant<br>    - Albert Cohen – may be developed due to a subculture and not just one individual + didn’t take non-utalitarian crimes into account like vandalism<br>    - Country can be deviant eg – Pakistan<br>    - | George Mead<br><br>ROLE TAKING!!!!!<br><br>Dynamicism, self identity, reflexivity, self objectification                                                    | - uses symbolic interactionism to analyze the role of social interactions and significant symbols in dev of self and mind<br>- CH Cooley – looking glass self<br>    - We imagine what other think of us<br>    - Imagine ow we appear before others<br>    - We change our mood accordingly<br>    - This is social self – ability to be both object and subject – think what others are thinking of him<br>- Chicago school and the father of symbolic interactionism<br>- **Self and society are twin born**<br><br>Self and society<br><br>- Social act is when two or more people interact and communicate with each other and can **be simple or complex** transactions<br>- **Society is sigma of social acts**<br>- Gestures are the key mechanism through which social acts **are affected**<br>- **Use significant symbol or gesture**<br>- Gesture or symbol is basic mechanism of a Social act and can be **verbal or physical**, creating **significant gestures which have a common meaning to the people involved**, esp language which distinguishes humans from others<br>- Benefits of significant gestures<br>    - Gesture and meanings are communicated (language – meaning is also communicated)<br>    - Elicit the same response between speaker and receiver<br>    - Potential of effective communication<br>    - Enables human thinking, which is the interaction between human and his mind; it is the conversation between I and me<br>- He also says that social group comes first and it leads to the dev of self conscious mental state<br>- Mind and Consciousness is developed due to presence of an existing social group and is responsible for social thinking<br>- These symbols are used across different role taking stages to develop the notion of self and mind – and then go<br><br>Self<br><br>- Self: ability to be both object and subject<br>    - At birth we are devoid of social experiences;<br>    - We are not born with it; social relations and activities help in development of self; self develops with reflexivity<br>    - Self rises with human development and social interactions/ relations/ activities<br><br>These interactions are facilitated by symbols and language<br><br>- - Mind and self are dialectically related<br>    - Body is not self; it becomes self when mind is developed<br>    - **Self and reflexiveness** is important for development of mind. Mind develops within the social process<br>    - Mind involves thought process oriented towards problem solving<br>    - Self presupposed social process<br>    - Once self is developed, it can be maintained even without social contact<br>    - Reflexitivity – unconsciously put yourself in place of others and act as they act<br>    - With development of self, People can evaluate themselves as they will be evaluated from outside **(Looking glass self theory of Cooley)**. This development of self happens in phases and hence is an **evolutionary process + self helps in internal interaction as well as comm with mind**<br>    - Understand how to do conversation with others – what is being said and what needs to be said next<br>    - Over a period of time we start - Role taking by taking role of others and then looking at oneself (reflexivity)<br>    - This self identity or self awareness takes place as a result of role taking – reflexivity process of how others see us<br>    - Preparatory stage – as an infant, limited social experience and hence no role taking -> mimics without understanding the behavior<br>    - Play stage: when the children take particular roles or discrete others and have limited development of self as they start understanding language; lack a more generalized sense of self<br>        - Eg – doll mother -> understands mother and her are diff – so partial self awareness<br>    - Game stage: when they grow up, they can become self in full sense; take role of all others (generalized others)<br>        - Only when we take role of generalized others, we are complete members of society<br>        - Help in development of organized activities<br>        - We can do abstract thinking and objectivity<br>        - But there are many generalized others in the society, because there are many groups in the society<br>        - As a result each self is different based on the groups it’s a part of<br>        - Hence it s not that there is no individuality and everyone is a conformist<br>    - Most likely do what is expected | Inequality                                                                                                                                                 | Intro<br><br>- Modern idea of equality emerged from enlightenment as well as rise of capitalism with bourgeoise challenging nobility hereditary rights<br>- Social differences are historical, but attachment of value to these differences leads to inequality<br>- Different individuals are associated to different groups and evaluated differently<br>- Equality means members of society have equal access to wealth, power, prestige etc<br>- Patterns of difference in access to social -economic opportunities and resources lead to social inequality<br>- Can be micro or macro (developed vs developing vs underdeveloped vs least developed countries)<br>- It is a mental construct via differentiation (people with differences), ranking (preliminary ranking based on comparison), evaluation (attaching values to the differences), rewarding<br>- Andre Beteille -> Inequality can be harmonic (inequality preached as a practice eg caste historically) or disharmonic (where preached vs practice are different)<br><br>Reasons<br><br>- Rosseau: 2 types of inequality (physical and moral/ political)<br>- Bourdieu: 4 types of inequality and deprivation (economic capital, social capital, cultural capital, symbolic capital); these capitals may overlap – ALWAYS USE IN INEQUALITY<br>- Marx: Due to difference in ownership of means of production and dependency theory<br>- Functionalists: Inevitable to be able to perform all jobs<br>- Haralombus and Holborn (Sociology – themes and perspectives): Inequality of power and inequality of material well being. They become repressive when aggressilevly enforced such as slavery<br>- Peter saunders – equality of 3 types – legal equality, equality of outcome, equality of opportunity (meritocracy – everyone has an equal chance of becoming unequal)<br><br>Impact<br><br>- Such inequalities lead to poverty and deprivation (Merton)<br>    - Deprivation has multiple dimensions such as health edu sanitation info legal aid etc<br>    - can be absolute or relative deprivation<br>- **Goran** Therborn (the killing fields of inequality): Analyzed types and impact of inequality incl. ill health, crime, discrimation, poverty, health edu; exclusion of poor has to be eliminated<br>    - caused by **systematic arrangements**, processes and distributive actions, both individual and collective<br>- **Wilkson and prickett (The spirit level: why more equal societies almost always do better**)– not only harmful for individual but also dysfunctional for society<br>- Bryan turner (EQUALITY) – Equality includes fundamental equality of a person,, equality of opportunity, equality of condition, equality of outcome<br><br>Contemporary<br><br>- Modern measures: GINI Coefficient, human development index<br>- Provisions: Constitution DPSP, FR, Schemes like PDS, DBT, Subsidies, social security, progressive taxation<br>- India: 10% people hold 70% wealth<br>- Sen – I believe all problems in the world come from inequality of one kind or another<br>- Equality can be legal, political, economic, social<br><br>Talent Allocation: • Increased mobility can lead to a more efficient allocation of talent,<br><br>Social and Cultural Integration: • Mobility can promote greater social and cultural integration, | Poverty                                                                                                                                                    | Intro<br><br>- John Sinclair and FM Eden - Social problem involving lack of access to material resources required for basic subsistence and minimum standard of life (Amartya sen and mdp)<br>- Ruth lister (Poverty) – definition of poverty has important implications for **political, policy and academic** discourse<br>    - Defined in economic and material well being terms only<br>- Absolute poverty (poverty line at 1.9), relative poverty such as Stauffer’s American soldier or multi-dimensional poverty (imp for socioligists to evaluate if other needs beyond basic economic needs are also being met for a decent quality of life)<br><br>Dimensions<br><br>- Dimensions of poverty: social, cultural, digital, political, info, health, edu, finance<br><br>Causes<br><br>- Causes of poverty: economic, social, cultural factors<br>- **Different views on origin and prevalence of poverty**<br>    - Blame the poor (limited motivation) or blame the system approach (limited avenues for social mobility)<br>    - The cultural perspective<br>        - (Oscar Lewis – social atmosphere of poor perpetuate poverty); tribals are poorer than average population by more than 40%. | Social stratification                                                                                                                                      | Intro<br><br>- Tumin – arrangement of any social group or society hierarchy of positions that are unequal with regard to power, property, social evaluation and psychic gratification<br>- Sutherland and Maxwell: As a process of differentiation, which places some people higher than others<br>- Structural hierarchy with some strata placed above others<br><br>Process<br><br>- 4 steps followed:<br>    - Differentiation (which may exist naturally or by society and can be perceived by people in society)<br>    - Evaluation: evaluate in terms of prestige, status, honour, income etc, leading to inferiority/ superiority<br>    - Ranking: when different strata are compared<br>    - Reward: reward/ punish different strata based on the evaluation and ranking attached<br><br>Types<br><br>- Can be open or closed stratification. Open stratification has social mobility to move from one strata to another (eg, bureaucracy)<br>- But stratification need not always be hierarchical; Dipankar Gupta: “**it will be futile and even capricious to hierarchize languages or religions or nationalities**<br><br>Sources<br><br>- Bottomore defined 4 types of social stratification traditionally – slaves (vs citizens), estate (during feudal time – nobility, clergy and serf), caste (SS by birth), class (by economic factors)<br>- Social stratification by functionalists<br>    - Stratas exist to be able to perform certain functions/ menial jobs in the society<br>    - Parsons:<br>        - Every society is based on consensus of norms and values due to cybernatic<br>        - He said there are differential rewards for differential strata in society<br><br>![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 59.png>)<br><br>- - - These differential rewards lead to stratification<br>        - Stratification is inevitable as value consensus s an integral part of all types of society<br>        - functional requisites, explaining each function is a pre-requisite to the survival of a social system.<br>        - Critique<br>            - Dahrendorf: stratification is a result of closely related trinity of power, norms and sanction and not only functional pre-requisites<br>            - Elite self recruitment not considered<br>            - Turner: structural Functionalism struggles with illegitimate teleologies<br>            - Beck and Baudrillard – caste system rigidity cant be explained and now, inequalities are more individual based<br>            - Gouldner – social stratification not inevitable and criticizes for justifying inequality<br>            - Also, Parson’s theory exist only if everyone has equal opportunities<br>    - WL Warner<br>        - Further propagated the concept of differential rewards based on social status as a base of stratification<br>        - Social status – edu, occupation and income<br>        - _The social life of modern community_<br>    - Davis and Moore (**Some principle of social stratification**)<br>        - MERITOCRACY<br>        - SOCIAL STRATIFICATION AND INEQUALITY<br>        - ROLE ALLOCATION<br>        - VALUE CONSENSUS<br>        - SCARCITY OF TALENT AND DIFFERENTIAL REWARD<br>        - MOTIVATION<br>        - COMPENSATION<br>        - Human societies are universally stratified<br>        - Some positions are seen as functionally more imp than others<br>        - Talent is considered scarce and hence social stratification is a way of attracting talented and meritocratic people in role allocation to fill more imp positions<br>        - These positions are exclusive and less in number<br>        - A lot of people are dependent on them<br>        - More important positions are paid a higher reward since they have talent and skills which are unique, and its needed to motivate them to service these positions<br>        - They have to sacrifice when they undergo training as some functions are more important than others<br>        - Hence social stratification is inevitable in any society<br>        - Rewards attract as an incentive to attract these people – status, wealth, power<br>        - They don’t question system but accept, creating a value consensus in society<br>        - Relevance in India – NEET, UPSC, SSC - np, as power is a more dominant source of inequality rather than awards + people of same talent get occupy higher position<br>        - PINK COLLARIZATION, SOCIAL CAPITAL, STRUCTURAL CONSTRAINTS, GLASS CEILING, CASTE BASED CONSTRAINTS, POVERTY AND INEQUALITY<br>- Marx<br>    - Strat refers to economic and vertical division in society<br>    - Stratification based on ownership of means and forces of production<br>    - Structure: have/ have nots<br>    - A minority has ownership of resources, leading to oppression of the lower strata who don’t own these resources<br>    - Hence product of dialectical materialism, unequal ownership and subsequent class formation<br>    - Consequence: class struggle<br>    - Universality: end of stratification with communism<br>    - Charles Murray – concept of underclass – people with little bargaining power and at mercy of employer eg minority and women<br>    - Critique<br>        - Social mobility will increase in future, with emergence of welfare state and middle class<br>- Weber<br>    - Saw stratification in a multi-dimensional view of class, status and power called trinitarian model<br>    - Happens because of unequal distribution of property, prestige, power<br>    - Class:<br>        - Defined class as a group of people with similar positions in the economic or market position, because of which they have similar life chances<br>        - Not a community<br>        - Related to unequal distribution of economic rewards<br>        - People with similar life chances have similar class<br>            - Life chance is level of opportunity to access good standard of life<br>        - Based on education and skills and not means of Production ownership<br>        - 4 classes: propertied upper class, property less white collar, petty bourgeoisie, manual workers<br>        - Have different skills and ownership on means of production<br>        - No evidence of polarization – instead middle class will swell (proliferation of MC)<br>        - No difference of community feelings (unlike Marx) – not a homogenous group because diff interests and prestige enjoyed differentiate their collective - consciousness<br>        - No abolition of pvt property – equality not necessary, infact it will take new forms<br>    - Status group<br>        - **Social group awarded similar amount of honor and share same position**<br>        - These are communities<br>        - Can be status group (a group of people enjoying honour from majority of individuals) or status less group<br>        - Related to unequal distribution of honour<br>        - Practice endogamy eg – inter caste<br>        - They follow certain rules and manners<br>        - Pass on same value system to next gen<br>        - Enjoy prestige due to their lifestyle (Refers to way of life chosen by individual)<br>            - Internal to individual – choice is individuals<br>            - Eg – IAS officer 2 sons – each has same life chance but diff lifestyle<br>            - Defines honour inequality in society (lifechance defines eco inequalities in soc)<br>            - Doesn’t necessarily lead to status inequalities<br>        - Eg – president delegation, exclusive clubs like gymkhana, sherpas, brahmans<br>        - Closed status group (closure)<br>        - Possession of property, and resource not always associated with status<br>        - Dependent on multiple factors such as knowledge, occupation, income, honour, social capital etc.<br>        - Consumers of goods and not producers of goods<br>        - Aware of their status eg Brahmins or untouchables<br>        - Traditional societies – ascriptive, modern societies achievement based<br>        - Usually more closed groups and have certain qualifiers for others<br>        - Pakulski and waters – status is becoming more imp than economic class as cons is based on status (eg spending on marriage based on status and not economic capacity)<br>    - Party<br>        - Parties are structures who want to gain power (be at state or non state institution)<br>        - Usually represent class or status groups (not always)<br>        - Parties of patronage and parties of principle<br>    - Hence he concluded power property and prestige not necessarily correlated. Goes against Marxist idea of eco as deterministic factor<br>    - Application<br>        - Socio economic caste census – looks at diff<br>        - Surveys are very comprehensive<br>        - Eg – global gender gap, MDI<br>    - Critique<br>        - Cellia Heller: Status and class often inter related<br>            - Counter – usually bit not always + homo a status group across classes<br>        - Ulrich Beck:<br>            - Risk based stratification - inequality based on risk taking capability<br>            - Induced by modern society such as terrorism, innovation etc<br>        - Marxist – conflict theory<br>        - Feminist – ignores gender stratification<br>        - Runciman – 7 classess and not 4<br>        - CW Mills – new type of power elite<br>    - Illustrations<br>        - Individual with wealth may command little prestige or power eg = lottery, inherit wealth<br>        - Individuals with status may not have wealth eg – social woker, great Thunberg, people who are ascetics<br>        - With status but no power – eg ex PM, e x bureucrats, celebs<br>        - Status could be source of power – media ccelebs, Kangana ranaut<br>        - Wealth could be source of power – ambani<br>    - Reality is **multi dimensional if unit of analysis is individual actor**, class power status may not correlate. and preconceived notions<br>- Multiple theories were formulated to support this claim in 18th and 19th century incl: (overt racism)<br>    - White Man burden by Rudyard Kipling<br>    - Ethnocentrism<br>    - Apartheid<br>- Formed the basis of colonial imperialism and Hitler to promote Aryans<br>- But after WW2, race based discrimination has been legally abolished; so race | Ethnicity based stratification                                                                                                                             | Socially constructed stratification – both race and ethnicity<br><br>\|   \|   \|<br>\|---\|---\|<br>\|Race\|ETHNICITY\|<br>\|- Describes physical traits like skin, hair, facial and body type\|- Refers to cultural traits like religion, language, food, nationality\|<br>\|- Race is inherited\|- Learnt and maintained though activities like wearing certain dress and eating certain kind of food\|<br>\|- Individuals usually belong to one race\|- Individual may belong to multiple ethnic groups – eg, individual could be afro-american protest charoci\|<br>\|- Often used as a marker of superiority and inferiority\|- Ethnicity are never arranged in hierarchies, rather viewed as diverse groups with diverse customs\|<br>\|- Punjabi, north Indian, Indian, language is also ethnic group,\|<br>\|- Similarity\|   \|<br>\|- Refers to unequal distribution of life chances between ethnic and racial groups<br>- Both are social constructs – not based on objective, biological or genetic differences rather products of social categorization<br>- Life chances depend on both eg – Black and white president<br>- Both impact social interactions – stereotypes, prejudices, biases<br>- Both have had historical significance – both have played significant role in shaping societies<br>- Modernization school believes that ascriptive status like caste, ethnicity, race, linguistic identity declines and achievement orientation based on individual merit becomes the new norm (Parsons)<br>- Ethnicity today is hyper visible in following fronts<br>    - Rise of ethnic associations – caste based associations eg Jatt Mahasabha – pressure group and political parties<br>    - Linguistic associations – Dravidian samiti, hindi sabha<br>    - Religious groups – hindu Mahasabha, hindu Mahasabha<br>    - Regional identities (gorkha, boro, Khalistan)<br>- Ethnic identity is visible in politics – policisation of ethnicity and ethno- nationalism eg gorkha and bodo regiment (Earnest Geller)<br>- Ethnic diversity is hyper visible in social media and bollyeood eg – big fat Punjabi wedding , Haryana – stereotypes<br>- Caste relevance<br><br>In workplace<br><br>- Bamboo– refers to non-natives like non whites from rising to top positions – leads to dev of sticky floor phenomena by which young Asian professionals are often trapped in low level, low mobility jobs<br>- canvas ceiling – jobs not suitable for whites – usually migrants in specific kinds of jobs eg nursing – most are black , security guard Nepal (bahadur), truck drivers, restaurants in CP<br><br>Income level in USA<br><br>- White Americans earn disproportionately higher than black americans and indo americans (30% are living in poverty)<br>- Colin<br><br>Politics – white dominant, hindu dominated<br><br>Edu – ivy leagure – whites protestants\|   \|<br><br>- Ethnic group is a group that shares some socio-cultural characteristics or markers<br>- Socially designed category of people who identify with each other based on common ancestors, culture, religion, national origin or lifestyle<br>- Three key conceptions – biological, cultural, psychological<br>- It is a very elastic concept. It is possible to change ethnicity by adaptation, migration, language shift, culturalization etc.<br>    - Melting pot – when different ethnicities merge into one, such as US<br>    - Pluralist co-existence like India<br>    - Antagonist co-existence such as Sri Lanka (Tamil and Singhalese)<br>- Often result in exclusionary devices such as inter-ethnicity marriage or discrimination as well discrimination -<br>    - Tech advancement –<br>    - Sons of soil – Khalistan<br>    - Internal colonialism – dominant community vs periphera – pathalgadhi<br>    - Identity loss – bangaldesh<br> | Status based stratification                                                                                                                                | - While class based in based on economic condition, status based stratification is based on prestige, honour, social and cultural capital, personal qualities, education, fame, family etc.<br>- In traditional societies, it was ascriptive but becoming both ascriptive and achieved in modern societies<br>    - Status evolves with evolution of society<br>    - Leads to opening of strata – more dynamic as ascriptive status has to be justified by nobility<br>- Difference from class<br>    - Based on social criteria, not economic<br>    - Aware of the social status, whereas difficult to be aware in class<br>    - Generally more closed than class, esp when ascriptive<br>    - Concerned with consumption and not production<br>- It is more closed and promotes social discrimination and inequality; social groups focused on self interest and restrict others from joining<br>- Weber: 3 factors of stratification<br>- Waters: status is becoming more imp in post industrial societies with rising consumerism<br>    - Consumption is based on status<br>- Frank parkin – social closure - don’t allow outsiders to take awards<br>- WL Warner – focus on status with edu, occupation and income<br>- Bourdieu (4 types and identitites shaped more on lifestyle choices) - An invitation to reflexive sociology<br>- Examples of status change: Sanskritization, westernization Upward mobility more common as demand for unskilled workers are reducin<br>- Examples – Sanskritization, education, migration, urbanization<br><br>Open and closed systems<br><br>- Sorokin in his “socio cultural dynamics” says no society is is completely closed or open, some kind of fluidity is always present<br>- Open system (Dipankar Gupta) – a stratification of society which is legitimized on basis of merit and hierarchy is quantifiable in nature (based on merit) eg – class system<br>- Closed system – based on differences (qualitative) assume hierarchy is a closed system eg – class, gender, ethnicity, race<br><br>\|   \|   \|<br>\|---\|---\|<br>\|Open\|closed\|<br>\|- Mobility is encouraged\|- Mobility is discouraged\|<br>\|- Eg\|- eg\|<br>\|- at an individual level\|- at group level\|<br>\|- does not displace already existing elites\|- does displace already existing elite – shudras were allowed to sanskritize, not Dalits (MNS) , LGBTQ marriage<br>- if mobility – challenge societal norms, displace (MNS), redstribute wealth and economic resources\|<br>\|- social system maintains equilibrium despite mobility\|- May disrupt or develop strain with mobility\|<br>\|- Class hierarchy is variable sum game\|- Status hierarchies are 0 sum game\|<br>\|- Meritocratic society\|- Ascriptive society\|<br><br>- AB – open system of stratification is one in which diff components of identity are recombined in diff ways/ diverse ways (asymmetrical nature)<br>    - Caste 1, class 2, power 3<br>- AB – closed system is one where diff components are combined in the same mobility way (C1, C2, P3)<br>- Embourgeoisement – working class to middle class – upward vertical mobility – hence open mibolity as prolet become MC<br>- Goldthorpe – Affluent worker – short range and inter-generational<br>    - Out of 80, only 2 went up<br>- IHDS – on social mobility – most upper posts upper caste and bottom are lower caste tribes and women<br>- . | Work                                                                                                                                                       | - Usage of physical and mental effort for production of goods and services that cater to human needs<br>- In eco sociology, it means activity which results in paid employment, reward or contract<br>- But can include unpaid work also<br>- Domestic division of labour also – so obligatory work also<br>- Marx: first sociologist to examine work in factories. He identified concepts of alienation and de-skilling<br>- Weber: new authority with new bureaucratic orgs of work<br>- Durkheim – DOL strengthens organic solidarity due to increased moral density. Rapid change in society however can lead to normlessness, which he called is an anomie<br><br>Importance of work<br><br>- Source of income<br>- Influences all other aspects of society, esp class and gender based stratification and social mobility<br>- Promotes creativity and constructive critical thinking for problem solving<br>- Helps in building social capital by new contracts and relations<br>- Affects status (Warner)<br>- Personal identity and growth of “I”<br><br>Worker vs labor<br><br>- Worker is someone not in a managerial position<br>- But also has voluntary choice of work unlike labor who is forced to work due to lack of choice for any reason<br>- Workers have different skills and manage different portfolios based on requirement<br><br>New ways of working<br><br>- Also includes studying motion of worker while completing task – includes movement of body and limbs<br>        - DOL – break work into specialized components and allocate work to specialized worker<br>        - Monitoring – performance to be monitored supervised by managers<br>        - Scientific selection of workers on merit<br>        - Incentivize workers - Mgt should provide incentives for workers to complete the job quickly and punish inefficnet workers<br>    - Efficiency, calculative, standardization, control over workers – all lead to rationalization of work place<br>    - Demerits – **reduces worker to economic man** (only concerned about how quickly completely task than how he felt doing it), cog in machine, alienated, replaceable by machine , reduce bargaining power of workers, de-skilling of worker (**Braverman**)<br>    - Taylorism in post industrial society – emotional work (managed heart – Arlie Hoschild)<br>        - Refers to app of scientific mgt to digital era – applicable to knowledge workers and service workers<br>        - Involves tech to monitor and optimize worker productivity, smart sensor, vc record, AI chatbot, automation, biometric, panoptical<br>    - Eg – amazon<br>- Henry ford – used scientific in automobile – specialized machines to boost economies of scale + increment of min wage to increase mass consumption<br>    - Mass prod, cons, long term commitment to worker, productivity linked wage, collective bargaining agreement<br>- Elton Mayo – Mayoism – Human resource theory – Mayo believed we should treat worker as employee and move beyond concept of economic man. | CA                                                                                                                                                         | - Gig economy<br>    - Mechanism of Work where workers perform work on a casual or task (gig) basis via a digital platform and receive commission in return, without any social security<br>    - Access to work is difficult and based on performance and ratings – involves taskification of work<br>    - They have freedom to select the work they chose and can chose to not performa a task – have more freedom vs a 9-5 job. But they don’t get any social security and hence called “platform capitalism” by Srineck<br>    - Code on Social security 2020 defined the social security arising out of a gig work relationship<br>    - Always existed but have changed nature with penetration of internet<br>    - Includes jobs like:<br>        - Crowdsourcing work: where work is perfomed from home<br>            - Online freelancing: Fix own rates and conditions with clients<br>            - Microtask work : a large work divided into small bits and sourced<br>            - High skilled work – marketing tech<br> | Power                                                                                                                                                      | - Weber (economy and society): Ability of individuals or groups to influence others to carry out their will, in a communal action, even against will of others who are participating in the social action<br>    - Economy and society<br>    - Domination used to study history – domination is chance of man to get his command obeyed<br>    - Types<br>    - Zero sum game<br>    - Power in a system is constant and hence limited in quantum<br>    - Authority is the form of power which is legitimate<br>    - One exercises power at the expense of other<br>    - Traditional, charisma, rational legal<br>    - Paul Du Gay, Bureaucracy has unmatched ethos which include equal treatment of all despite different race, colour or caste<br>- Functional view: power is possessed by society and not individuals, where some social positions are more important than others and exercise power through them<br>    - Parsons –<br>        - Located in G of AGIL<br>        - Individuals deposit power in political leader just like they deposit it in bank<br>        - Leaders in return deliver infra, growth which caters collectively to members<br>        - Egs – universalization of edu, 100% sanitation<br>        - If collective goals are realized, systemic power increase, else decline<br>        - Function of power is to fulfill collective goals and maintain equilibrium<br>        - "Power is not a zero-sum game". Discuss with reference to Weber's and Parsons's views. **(2014/I/6a/20)**<br>- Marx: of<br>    - State represents interests of capitalists<br>    - Power is concentrated in the hands of the dominant group (the haves) used for exploitation of have nots<br>    - Suggested making a political party of workers<br>    - Source of power is the economic infrastructure<br>    - Zero sum<br>    - Have nots are exploited when they have false consciousness<br>    - Only when there is collective ownership on means of production, power will go back to people<br>    - Evidence to support Marxism<br>        - Effects of decisions – concentration of power in the hand of a few capitalists who then monopolize power in society<br>        - Concessions to working class<br>        - Non decision making – John Urry criticizes Dahl that only those issues come up which are defined by bourgeoise and only safe decisions taken. | Classical elite                                                                                                                                            | - Society is divided into 2 main groups – ruling minority and ruled majority; egalitarian society like democracy is a myth/ utopia<br>- Ruling minority has physical and psychological attributes which are basis of power<br>- Pareto:<br>    - **Mind and society**<br>    - power is possessed by few due to their physical psychological qualities and **these qualities remain the same at all times**<br>        - 2 types : governing : play direct or indirect role and non-governing elites<br>        - Non govt**- such as economic (wealth), sports, art, ethic (virtuous)**<br>    - these qualities divided ruler and ruled<br>    - elite refer to those who excel<br>    - two groups of governing elite: lions and foxes (<br>    - lions rule by force, courage, decisive<br>    - foxes by cunningness and have manipulation skills<br>    - Dictators/ royals/ conservative fall in lions<br>    - Innovative/ materialistic goal/ imaginative cunning people like Chanakya and Maurya fall in foxes<br>    - Circulation: when one set decays or loses vigour, replaced by other set of elites ; can be 2 types – gov and non-gov, or lions and foxes<br>    - Due to loss of faith, corrupt, loss of transperacy<br>    - Circulation not ltd to politics – seen in religious groups, biz also eg startup vs capitalist<br>    - Borrowed from Machaivelli<br>    - Each kind of elite lacks the qualities of the counterpart<br>    - Masses lack rational capacity and hence are dominated – since they don’t have rational capacity, its less likely that there will be a revolution<br>    - Circulation of Elites leads to social change in society.<br>    - Criticism<br>        - Parsons Criticism : no distinction between democracy, communism, fascism etc<br>        - No way of measuring qualities<br>        - Difference between lion and fox is merely style of rule<br>        - Altruism -people do charity not for power<br>        - Modern society is complex and there are multiple sources of power centres<br>        - Bottomore: “Elites and society” elite circulation may not always be there as revolutionary intellectuals exist<br>        - DIFFERENT types of rules – no difference<br>        - CW mills<br>        - Pluralist theory<br>        - In response to Marxist claim that class struggle will lead to an egalitarian society with no private ownership<br>        - History is never ending circulation of elites<br>        - **Karl Mannheim**: In a democracy, there are various pulls and pushes that shape policy; people remove if they are not satisfied<br>        - **Justifies inequality and restricts social mobility**<br>    - **Relevance today**<br>        - **Economic inequality observed**<br>        - **Highly relevant in 2 party democracies like USA**<br>        - **Globalization – IMF WB show circulation on global scale**<br>- Mosca<br>    - **The Ruling class**<br>    - Better organizational skills<br>    - A few who dominate and others who are dominated and is inevitable<br>    - Agreed that there a few who dominate, but qualities are not the same all the time and vary from society to society and time to time<br>    - There are socialical and personal factors affecting rule<br>    - Democracy actually reflects the concerns of the elite and masses are a group of passive unconcerned people<br>    - Ruler can be elite (political or property) or semi-elite (like managers)<br>    - Elites are constrained by social factors and hence rules are not completely powerless in a democracy<br>- Robert Michels – developed ILOO to explain why masses cannot rule over society even in democratic states or socialist parties – there is tendency of tiny organized minority elites<br>    - Oligarchy – concentration of power with few minority elite<br>    - Iron law – tendency of an org to develop tiny organized elite in any organisation<br>    - few dominate power<br>    - Because they have access to information<br>    - Limited accountability<br>    - Elite rule is inevitable in society as it is a technical and tactical necessity<br>    - Iron law of oligarchy<br>    - Decisions in democracy are taken by the few elite who possess power and hence rule is inevitable<br>    - People are not rational – hence ruled<br>    - Though mosca agrees that elites can be drawn from public and wide background<br>    - Features<br>        - Concentration of power eg – despotism by dynastic rule<br>        - Lower mass participation eg voter turnout<br>        - Low trust of people eg farmer bill<br>        - Conservative nature<br><br>![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 64.png>)<br><br>- - Criticism<br>        - Robert Dahl – in Democracy and Its Critics, - reduced entire democracy to oligarchy<br>- CW Mills:<br>    - **The power elite**<br>    - Elite rule is inevitable and a small group of elite exrcised **disproportionate amount of power**<br>    - So, key people in key institutes is power elites<br>    - According to his US study, power lies with institutions and not personal qualities of individuals or psychological<br>    - Doesn’t mean they don’t use psychological but primary source is institution<br>    - Certain institutions occupy pivotal positions and the elite comprise those who “**command post**” in these institutions and monopolize power<br>    - He called this power elite – which consists of military, federal govt and corporations<br>    - Cohesiveness is strengthened by the fact that they often have similar social background and interests and frequent exchanges with each other as well as engage amongst themselves<br>        - Eg – ivy leagure, men, white, US<br>        - Endogamous, social closure<br>        - Global influence<br>        - Have unlimited power to manipulate masses - manipulate to justify work in own interest<br>        - A lot of power and limited accountability<br>    - Big corporations have these elite in boardrooms eg WWII<br>    - Minority of power elite<br>    - Elite Self recruitment<br>    - Significance<br>        - Central govt makes policy for eco growth<br>        - Congress, caste, regional<br>    - Vernacular or regional from low caste and non congress front coming to power elite<br>- Badri Narayan – bihar – 1948 – 1980s -2000 :<br>    - 1948: hegemony of kayasthas, brahmins, bhumihars (congress)<br>    - 1980s – Kurmi, koeri, Yadav (non congress)<br>    - 2000s – Dalit politics – chamars -> penetration of power to lower<br>    - At surface looks democratization since 50s, however, one set of elite replaced by another committee<br>- Robert Dahl: CW Mills has circumstantial evidence; power is disprersed – who governs? Interest groups<br>- Dahl – they work for welfare of people<br>- Arnold Rose: Elite groups don’t go hand in glove like Mills said. They take the decisions in consultation with various interest groups<br>- Public opinion matters<br>- Karl Mannheim: In a democracy, there are various pulls and pushes that shape policy; people remove if they are not satisfied<br>- Thompson – they don’t take decisions all on own but have to give concessions<br><br>Common features of classical elite theory<br><br>- Ruling minority, ruled majority<br>- Masses are not rational and hence unaware<br>- Self recruitment and system closure<br>- Work for own self interests<br>- Take decisions for society eg Hiroshima nagaski<br>- Power is concentrated<br>- Power is zero sum game<br>- They are v selfish and aim to fulfil own self interest<br><br>**Differences between Pareto and MILLS:**<br><br>**Nature of Elite**:<br><br>Mills' power elite consists of a triad of political, economic, and military leaders collaborating for<br><br>shared interests.<br><br>Pareto emphasizes the natural and cyclical nature of elites, with different groups rising to power over<br><br>time.<br><br>Mosca focuses on the political class as the dominant elite, emphasizing the control of political<br><br>institutions.<br><br>**Interconnectedness:**<br><br>Mills emphasizes the interconnectedness of institutions, with the power elite operating across<br><br>various sectors.<br><br>Pareto and Mosca focus more on the rotation of elites and the dominance of specific groups in<br><br>particular spheres.<br><br>**Elitist Circulation:**<br><br>While Pareto and Mosca highlight the circulation of elites, Mills' concept of the power elite suggests<br><br>a more stable and interconnected group.<br><br>**Sources of Power:**<br><br>Mills: Power is concentrated in the triad of political, economic, and military institutions, with<br><br>collaboration among these sectors. The power elite controls major societal decisions.<br><br>Pareto: Elites are characterized by those with superior abilities, whether intellectual, economic, or<br><br>political. Power may be held by those who excel in different spheres, and the elite naturally changes<br><br>over time.<br><br>Mosca: Power is concentrated in the political class, and the ruling minority emerges through<br><br>competition and the ability to manipulate political institutions.<br><br>**Role of Ideas and Values:**<br><br>Mills: Emphasizes the role of shared values and ideas among the power elite in maintaining their<br><br>dominance. The elite class has a cohesive worldview that guides decision-making.<br><br>Pareto: Focuses on the circulation of elites based on their abilities and the emergence of new elites<br><br>with different values and ideas over time.<br><br>Mosca: Highlights the manipulation of ideas and ideologies by the political class to maintain control.<br><br>The ruling minority uses ideologies to justify its dominance.<br><br>**Social Mobility:**<br><br>Mills: The power elite remains relatively stable, with limited social mobility. The interconnectedness<br><br>of the elite class reinforces its stability.<br><br>Pareto: Recognizes the circulation of elites, suggesting that social mobility occurs as different groups<br><br>rise and fall in power.<br><br>Mosca: Acknowledges the possibility of individuals moving into the political class, but the overall<br><br>structure remains characterized by a minority in control.<br><br>**Conflict vs. Stability:**<br><br>Mills: Acknowledges the potential for conflict between the power elite and the wider society,<br><br>highlighting the possibility of tensions and power struggles | Nation and nationalism                                                                                                                                     | - Weber: Nation is a community of sentiments<br>- Nation is a **psychological concept** where consciousnesses is rooted in common identity from a shared history, culture, ideology<br>- Nationalism is an Ideology consisting of symbols and sentiments that provides sense of common political community<br>- Has a sense of pride, belonging and affiliation<br>- Nationalism can manifest in many forms:<br>    - single ideology (china)<br>    - religion (israel)<br>    - composite culture<br>    - poly-ethnic (usa),<br>    - coercive<br>    - of race and kinship – But F Schuman says if only race, would have disappeared because of migration, wars, conquests and travels<br>    - historical roots: culture, language, enemy<br>- Thomas Erikson: (ethnicity and nationalism) national and ethnicity are diff as a nation has multiple ethnicity<br>- Gellner: nation, nationalism and nation-state are newer concept from 18th century<br>- Pilkington: supported Gellner – only with advent of communication when people realized others as totally distinct from them<br>- Anthony smith: not a modern concept such as rise of Germany<br>- Benedict Anderson (imagined communities): don’t even know others but still have a sense of communion; bringing a change in the existing social order<br>            - **Social movement can be active**, or **outwardly directed to transform society** or **inwardly directed to change people involved**<br>        - Strain theory: developed by Neil Smelser<br>            - where there is a difference between societal norms and structural means, people feel the strain in society<br>            - 6 necessities for development of the strain and a social movement to emerge<br>                - Structural conduciveness – envt of society should be such that certain forms of protest can take place eg not monarch<br>                - Structural strain - which should be due to the structure of current social system – relative deprivation due to inequality eg caste system<br><br>![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 72.png>)<br><br>- - - - - Generalized belief – clearly defined and agreed belief by participants – growth and spread of belief<br>                - Precipitating factor – certain event should have happened – spark for collective action<br>                - Mobilization of participants – should have network and org to take the action<br>                - Lack of political control or too much control – how much control do the higher authorities have?<br>            - Social movement emerges in form of stages and believed in a multi-causal theory instead of mono-causation<br>        - Relative deprivation theory:<br>            - when people feel relatively deprived and are unhappy about certain things, they lead to collective action<br>            - criticism: people are often unhappy about certain things, doesn’t mean they always take collective action<br>        - resource mobilization theory (**Mccarthy Zald**, Tilly): **From mobilization to revolution**<br>            - any social movement possible only when material resources to sustain such as knowledge, money, crowd, network, charismatic leader, leadership, media, have to compete for it<br>            - criticism: doesn’t explain movements by farmers and peasants , new movements don’t need resources eg meTOO, arab spring – no resource<br>        - **political opportunity theory (Till and McAdam**)<br>            - movement possible not only with resource but if there is right political opportunity too in the system<br>            - refers to vulnerability of existing political system due to its own weakness, support of opposition or formation of faction within ruling or greater access to public participation through social media<br>        - Wallace: | Revolution                                                                                                                                                 | - Refers to a fundamental change in political power or org structure in a relatively short period of time<br>- A social movement which is radical with far reaching outcomes<br>- James Jasper: “ revolution at minimum aims to overthrow the state or power”<br>- Charles Tilly (European revolutions):<br>    - Revolution has long lasting impact on society<br>    - Outcome of power struggle amongst competing interest groups<br>    - 4 main components<br>        - The org<br>        - Mobilization of resources<br>        - Common interest<br>        - Opportunity<br>- Smelser: when equilibrium in society is disturbed, revolution takes place<br>- Theda Skockpol: took the idea of revolution from mere political control to agrarian social conflicts also<br>- Goldstone: Same social movement can be a revolution in one and normal movement in another eg – human rights protest in West vs China<br>- Marx: revolution as a result of class conflict<br>- Goodwin – differentiates in social movements based on intensity of change – conservative (Reformist) or radical (revolution)<br>- Usually is supported by a leader to align the functions of individuals and develop common ideology; justify the actions undertaken under revolution and articulates the interests and views of the participants<br>- Revolution never takes place in a society until social structure is ready for it<br>- Voltaire – crisis is the mother of change<br>- ![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 75.png>)J-curve theory which means a rise in prosperity reduces revolution; + not all poverty leads to social revolution and | Pressure group                                                                                                                                             | - Groups OF People who come together on basis of common opinions to influence power wielders<br>- Orgs that don’t aim to form a govt but influence the govt to pursue their own interests<br>- Validates theories of Dahl, Hunter and others<br>- Mckenzie – can be a protective group (SC ST) or Promotional group (envt)<br>- Gabriel almond – can be institutional interest group (for doctors only), non institutional (ascription, religion etc), associational (class) or spontaneous (Anomic)<br>- Durkheim – tool for associative democracy<br>- Functionalists – make the ground for effective political participation<br>- Giddens – they are carriers of democracy.<br>- Wyn Grant – supports elite pluralist theory -> number has greatly expanded and v few are unrepresented. Direct action increased<br>- Tools used<br>    - A: Articulate interest eg – harijan sevak sangh<br>    - B: Backdoor lobbying eg FICCI<br>    - D: Demonstrations and movements to promote interest of pressure group eg – Narmada Bachao<br>    - E: Provision of expertise eg – Greenpeace<br>    - E: Evidence based decision making eg ASER<br>    - F: FR protection<br>    - M: Mobilize public opinion through info dissemeniation eg – AIKS, IUCN<br>    - P: Political participation – transition from spectator to activist<br>    - V: Voice of voiceless eg women and SEWA<br>    - P: Petitions through PIL and reports -<br>    - S: Shapre public opinion<br>- Disadvantage – myopic, unconstitutional means, politicize, repressive<br>    - But calls Pressure Groups as ‘Disguised Bourgeoisie – legitimize hegemony – spread false consiousness – Gramsci<br>    - Robert michels<br>    - Myopic eg envt vs economy – hirakund dam<br>    - Unconst means eg lobbyng<br>    - Pluralistic stagnation - PG slow down economic growth<br>    - Conflict theorists – disproportionately favor the well represented, better funded pressure groups<br>    - Richard Heffernan – political participation may fall in long run when demands are not met and hence they feel disengaged<br><br>Milbirth – allows participation of public in politics – move from spectator to transitionlal actiivists;<br><br>\|   \|   \|<br>\|---\|---\|<br>\|Pressure group\|Political party\|<br>\|Group.. def\|Weber: organized structure which promotes candidates to contest election to get power\|<br>\|Is informal ; not registered mandatorily\|Registered with formal authority\|<br>\|Extra cons means to get way\|May / may not\|<br>\|May dilute on completion of interest\|Ideology for survival – don’t die, find new objectives or ideology\|<br>\|Self appointed members – not accountable to public\|Accountable\|<br>\|Don’t need ideology\|Pre requisite for formation - ideology\|<br>\|<br><br>Dynamic relation<br><br>1. they feel disenchanted, alienated and marginalized from main society (Troletsch)**<br>        - Some people find Church orthodox, rigid, impersonal, discriminatory or corrupt (eg – brahmin domination)<br>        - ![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 76.png>)Feature od modernization and secularization<br>        - **THEODICY OF Disprivilege**” where theodicy means religious explanation (when marginalized stand up against religious explanation which justifies their marginalization and that they will be rewarded in afterlife for their suffering on earth) ; sects provide an alternative path of redemption<br>        - Eg – dalit and mausmriti burning -> Jainism<br>        - **Bryan Wilson**: methodism is a response to new working class and the uncertainity of the newly settled industrial area<br>        - Steve bruce – as a result of rationalization, secularization, social differentiation<br>    - Roy Wallis: defined sect as a **deviant group** that sees themselves as uniquely legitimate<br><br>Internal<br><br>- - - People seek salvation in a sense of community offered<br>    - Reinhold Niebuhr: can be short lived or convert to dominant or full fledged religion<br>    - Hence, seek remedy, come as contradiction, create a counter culture, promote alternate ideology<br>    - But now not necessarly an economic phenomena – eg ISKCON<br>    - Eg – Calvinism, Jainism, Sikhism<br>    - Can add secularization critique – Stark and bain bridge + Peter berger<br><br>Cults<br><br>- The word cult has negative connotations in common sense with bizarre practices. But all religions were cults. Now use new religious movements used<br>- It is a type of religion which is believed to be established around a charismatic leader believed to possess extraordinary qualities<br>- Types of cults (ACC) – Roy Wallis<br>    - World rejecting – they see outside world as inherently evil and reject mainstream world and encourage followers to detach themselves from mainstream. Eg – people’s temple by Jim Jones, heavens gate, Osho<br>    - World accommodating – unlike world rejecting, don’t reject mainstream and unlike affirming, not obsessed with max potential of individuals eg brahm kumari<br>    - World affirming – they don’t reject mainstream material world, rather show how to extract max by unlocking potential. They promote enjoy life and make them better individuals. More like paid enlightenment similar to SHG eg vipassana, scientology<br>- Another – stark and brainbridge<br>    - Audience cults: least organized – little F2F interaction and passively engaged eg – books, lectures – Sadhguru<br>    - Client cults: more organized, and ongoing relationship between leaders and followers – more like adherents<br>    - Cult movements: satisfy all religious needs of followers<br>    - Satisfy needs of alienated sections of urban middle class youth<br>    - Is v transitory and irregular<br>    - Hence have different cult memberships ( can follow more than 1)<br>    - More in western society, after post war and created counter culture as they are materialistic but anxious<br>- Reasons for new cults<br>    - Provides sense of belongingness – this appeals to individuals who feel isolated or disconnected<br>    - Quick salvation – rapid solution to everyday life problem; Cults provide relief in current life itself, vs religion which provides relief in afterlife<br>    - Provides flexibility<br>    - Heterogeneity<br>    - Personalized services and highly accessible<br>    - To deal with inequalities – women/ lower caste<br>    - Social media influence<br>- So these are voluntary orgs in metropolitans to ease the sufferings in industrial societies<br>- Usually under a charismatic leader, with focus on individual experiences<br>- Trying to find man ki shanti; not really marginalized<br>- Usually a richer person – important clients<br>- V individualistic<br>- No ceoncept of membership or exclusivity<br>- Steve bruce – result of secularization<br>- Stark and Bainbridge: new religions or atleast new in a particular society<br>    - Something may be cult in one place but a religion in another eg ISCON<br>- Reasons for cult<br>    - Conflict in traditional modern society<br>    - Insecurity – both psychological and social<br>    - Inequality – rising inequality<br>    - Change – rapidly changing society, need some anchor in this change for peace<br>    - Free lunches: offered by sects (schools, hospitals)<br>    - Political patronage: offered owing to populist politics<br>- Denomination<br>    - When sect becomes more organized and institutionalized with larger following, it becomes a Denomination<br>    - Denomination is more acceptable in eyes of the church<br>    - Johnson: The line between church and denomination is not v clear, nor is the line between sect and cult is<br>    - Denomination has its own institution, following, ideaoligy and exists in parallel to church ; making it the base of a secular society<br>    - Howard Beckar: a denomination is a sect which has cooled down and become an institutionalized body rather than an active protest group<br>    - They lose their radicalism and dynamism<br>    - Attract people from all stratas (not just marginalized) and are usually in line with norms of society<br>- Church: established institution which generally accepts the norms of society and consider itself the guardian of social order<br>- **ROY WALLIS DIAGRAM**<br><br>**Difference between sect and cult**<br><br>- **In opposition to church eg- protestnt vs in linde eg – Calvinist**<br>- **Closed open**<br>- **Challenge domination eg jain**<br>- **Use forceful conversion vs social media**<br>- **Live vs with die with leader** | Secularization                                                                                                                                             | - Bryon Wilson – sec is process characteristised by decline of **significance of religious beliefs and practices** in **public life** – “**desaclerization of society**”<br>- It is an ongoing or continuous process<br>- Some observations<br>    - City dwellers less religious, village dwellers more religious<br>    - Men less, women more<br>    - Employed in factory, less religious R, unemployed – more less R<br>- In line with comte<br>- Levels of secularization by **Karel Dobbelaere**<br>    - Macro : religion losing significance at level of state, economy, edu – eg secularism<br>    - Meso : religious orgs mrore focused on public issues, not other world issues eg langar, school;<br>        - Hatching, matching, dispatching roles on decline – but case, religion still exists<br>    - Micro : decline of **collective beliefs** (Hinduism – polygamy, Triple talaq, untouchability)emergence of pvt belief, decline of church attendance (<br>    - Dobbelaere suggests secularization varies at diff rates in diff levels<br>- Weber - the rationalization of society led to the disenchantment of society and as a result religious motives for action were replaced by rational motives for action<br>- ![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 96.png>)<br>- Process: Theological - secularization – secular society<br>- Transformation of society from a closed identification of religious values and institutions to non-religious values<br>- Features<br>    - Decrease in >popularity of religion<br>    - Rationality -> humans find scientific solutions<br>    - Science<br>- Reasons > edu, westernaization, equality, science, industrialization, urbanization. | Revivalism                                                                                                                                                 | - Counter to secularization thesis. Refers to process where religions come back against the forces which are weakenging the religion. Religion re-asserts its influence through religious values, institutions and symbols in reaction to secularization process<br>- Gabriel Almond – society moving to enthusiastic revival of religion<br>- Reason<br>    - Globalization leading to homogenization )Anthony G)<br>    - Social media penetration resulting in rise of charismatic personalities and cults<br>    - Politicization of religion for vote bank mobilization<br>    - Role of media in **Ideology in media** – eg Mahabharat<br>    - Increasing disenchantment and alienation with rise of science has led to uncertainty<br>    - Ashutosh vaarshney – communalism and revivalis reactions to perceived threat to religious identities<br>    - Need for solace as science has led to rapid industrialization and instrumental rationality<br>    - Plalisation has led to antognostic competition between religions<br>- Forms<br>    - Fundamentalism<br>    - Increasing Orgs like NRMs<br>    - Fall of atheism – secular fail in US<br>    - Religious conversions – MARRIAGE OR ATROCITY EG TRIBES CHRISTIAN<br>    - Protests and movements around religious symbols – movements like construction of mosques and temples<br><br>Functions<br><br>- - **Can play positive role in social reforms like brahmo samaj** – **Faizan Mustafa**<br><br>Challenges posed by religious revivalism in a secular state<br><br>- - Restrict personal rights and liberties of Voltaire, Locke and Rousseau<br>    - Re-enforce pariarchy – reduce equality (Sylvia Walby)<br>    - Deters separation of state from religion<br>    - Communal clashes and fundamentalism<br>    - Change in education<br>    - Destruction of symbols of authority<br>- Antithesis to Comte and other theories which claim religion will end with positivism<br>- **Secularization is a feature of some societies**; not for all – it’s a matter of degree<br>- David Martin: taking a wider view of secularization<br>    - He says role of religion is changing in post modern society; which shows revivalism<br>    - Little trend towards secularization<br>- Jose Casanova: religious beliefs are not dying but coming back in public sphere; in new and unfamiliar forms<br>- Relevance today<br>- Turner – religion is not only a cognitive system but a meaningful experience<br>- Communalism<br>    - Political hegemony of certain social groups to get power and influence policy<br>    - | Fundamentalism                                                                                                                                             | - Conservative religious doctrine opposing modern value system in favor of restoring religious values<br>- Features<br>    - Literal interpretation of religious texts<br>    - Againt pluralism<br>    - Charismatic leadership - TN Madan eg - Eg skih movement by Bhindrawalla<br>    - Highly monistic philosophy<br>    - Against modern values of FR, gender, scientific theories such as marx, Darwin<br>    - Consider themselves guardians of religion<br>    - Use of modern tech like youtube<br>    - Endirse conservative political goals<br>    - Try to get political and edu power to bring change<br>- Is a revivalist philosophy that develops more during episodes of modernization<br>- Types<br>    - Religious fundamentalism<br>        - Christian fundamentalism – perceived moral crisis and need to go back to fundamentals for welfare of society<br>        - Islamic fundamentalism: attacks for power struggle and religion dominance; can lead to terrorist groups and attacks<br>    - Secular fundamentalism – **Grace Davie** – F not limited to religion. Rigid adherence to non religious beliefs may have common beliefs with religious fundamentalism eg<br>        - Sexual -strong enforcement of hetero beleifs<br>        - Economic - strong enforcement of one indicator of measuring development eg GDP for growth<br>        - Gender – strong enforcement of gender beliefs on diff sexes<br>        - Political - only one way to make policy – fascism , Nazism<br>- Trends – Israel, Khalistan<br><br>Reasons<br><br>- Claim to protectors of religion against from external threats eg – Afghanistan/ Myanmar against rohngyas perceived threat to buddhist majority<br>- High modernity and globalization responsible - **Anthony Giddens**<br>    - Modernity: diff lifestyles for everything and undermines traditional religious values<br>    - Hence, fundamentalists attract people to live a simple basic life in this complex world to go back to calmer period<br>- Avoid anxiety as **Secularists** didn’t talk anything about religion even when people wanted to hear it; hence fundamentalists emerged to fill vacuum<br>- Provides identity and sense of collective conscience: Identity loss, alientation, commoner, rootlessness - Clutch on to any common support eg RSS<br>- **Steve Bruce** – Infallibility and literal interpretation of single sacred test. Low scope for varied interpretation and hence strong ideological cohesion eg -Taliban<br>- Prescribe a way of life, confirming a happy and better age that will bring happiness and motivate commitment from followers<br>- Role of social media in faster mobilization for movement – fundamentalist movements are usually of collective character, usually under a charismatic leader<br>- Politicization of religion - **Almond et.al** – Fundemanetalists work to gain political power by undoing erosion of religious values by globalization ad modernity<br><br>Need to balance between religious fundamentalism and society welfare; secularism has not won yet
