| FAMILY and functions                                                                                                                                       | - George Murdock (social structure): (in 250 societies – both traditional and industrial)<br>    - Family is a universal social institution as it existed in all kinds of societies from hunting gathering to industrial societies characterized by …<br>    - Characteristics: common residence, economic cooperation and reproduction, adults of both sexes, atleast two of whom maintain a socially approved sexual relationship and one or more children, born or adopted, of the sexually cohabiting adults<br>    - Universal functions – 4<br>- Some variations may exist: black fams in US don’t have black males/ Nayars of Kerala, LGBTQ<br>- Family, marriage, household are basic units of society and form the foundation of a society<br>- Origin and functions<br>    - Evolution theory -><br>        - Frazer - Man lived alone in a cave and had promiscuous behavior so didn’t have a family<br>    - Feminist –<br>        - Fam is patriarchal to keep women subordinate to men. Legitimates gender inequality since childhood<br>        - Limits women to domestic role (Expressive role)<br>        - Fran Ansley – women provide emotional support to frustrated males in capitalist system<br>        - Margaret bentson – perpetuate unpaid labor<br>        - Murray strauss – marriage license is a hitting license<br>        - Sexual abuse, marital rape, violence<br>        - Diana Leonard – set of labor relations where men benefit from and exploit women<br>        - Calhoun – it is not the unit of family that leads to exploitation but family within a patriarchal and oppressive heterosexual structure<br>        - Critique – ignore the fact that they may have fought back against exploitation<br>            - DJH Morgan – families of traditional view were men were breadwinners is becoming less common now.<br>    - Marxists<br>        - Karl Marx: family promotes conformity under exploitation of haves + why imp – so that you have workforce<br>        - David cooper (death of family) – ideological conditioning in an exploitative society<br>        - Engels (origin of family, private property and state) – **materialistic evolutionary view** – as MOP matured, Private ownership emerged and to protect it and hence families emerged<br>            - Maintains private property – maintenance of inequality (Engels)<br>        - Zaretsky – fam as unit of consumption to enhance consumerism among members in society<br>            - Fam helps in maintaining stability of worker which is beneficial for capitalist<br>    - Critical<br>        - Normal bell - Emotionally disturbed child as a family scapegoat – used to relieve tension of parents<br>    - So not universal<br>    - Functional<br>        - GP Mudrock -4 functions – economic, regulate sexual relation , socialize children, control reproduction<br>        - **Parsons**<br>            - Two basic and irreductible functions of family<br>            - Primary socialization of children – children learns norm of society + name, basic upbringing<br>            - Stabilize adult personality – marriage creates human personalities and they need to be kept stable by marriage and relationship + overcome childish traits that they cant act in adulthood such as watching cartoons all day!<br>                - Warm Bath theory – take care after long day<br>            - Industrial societies have isolated nuclear families for easy mobility near industrial location<br>        - **Merton – latent and manifest role of family – keeps reproduction alive**<br>        - **Also imp for taking care of elderly, punishment for deviance from accepted norms so maintain social order**<br>        - Critique<br>            - Now depend more on peers/ friends than family<br>            - Adult stabilization by law and police now<br>            - However, people expecting more from a marriage and hence those marriages which would have survived earlier actually die away<br>            - Parsons accused of idealizing family with well adjusted spouse and children based on the “cereal family” – an ideal middle class family<br>    - Post modernists – new forms of family, highly fluid<br><br>Evolution of family<br><br>- Functionalists<br>    - Sexual needs, recreational, occupational, economic (extended family)<br>    - Now nuclear family – so only 2 functions of parsons; other have alternative institutes like creche and school<br>        - Fit for industrial society<br>        - Mobile and can generate saving and consumption<br>        - conjugal bonds strengthened<br>- Marxists (Engels)<br>    - Promiscuous hordes to patriarchal monogamous family<br>    - PH – no ownership, shared families, shared wealth<br>    - PMF – in order to save accumulated wealth -> made women exploited<br>- Post modern<br>    - Types of multiple forms only changing | Types and features                                                                                                                                         | - Features of a traditional family<br>    - Size of fam – can be extended, Joint family or nuclear – extended have horizontal or vertical nuclear families staying together<br>    - Authority- Patriarchal or matriarchal or filiocentric –<br>        - Parsons – males have institutional authority while females enjoy affective authority<br>    - Kinship bond – cane be Conjugal or consanguineal or fictive kins in rural – kinship neither conjugal or consanguineal and based out of friendship or religion<br>        - usually conjugal subordinate to consanguineal<br>    - Descent – matrilineal or patrilineal or ambilineal<br>    - Unit of production<br>    - Residence - matrilocal, patrilocal, neolocal, duolocal, avunculocal – eg nairs – visiting husband concept<br>    - Basis of marriage – polygamy, monogamy, polyandry<br>    - Name (patronymic, metronymic – kaushalayaputra – usually in polygamy)<br>    - DOL – usually based on sex-based roles – feminine and masculine<br>    - Ownership pattern – usually with adult male<br>    - Taboos like incest and vary from society to society<br>    - Raymond Firth – effective or non effective kin based on how much contact they have (two studies of kinship in london)<br>- Giddens – serial monogamy – multiple marriages and multiple divorces<br>- Willmott and young: majority people call atleast once at home; don’t leave contact completely<br>    - Babysitting by grandparents<br>    - USA – isolated nuclear family v rare – only when both were working and middle class; even rich keep network<br>    - Society evolved in 3 types of families<br>        - Pre-industrial family – both took up some part of the house<br>        - early industrial family – clear DOL with men working in industry and women at home<br>        - symmetrical family – help each other in chores<br>- Colin Bell: telecom and travel – quality has improved – **modified or dispersed extended family**<br>- Bade Thorne: **cereal family image – ad of cereal sellers –**<br>    - **think families are like Market is not big enough to achieve economies and keep prices low<br>- Theotonio Sanstos – “ a situation where the economy of certain countries is conditioned by the dev and expansion of another | Agents of social change                                                                                                                                    | - Three basic sources<br>    - Discovery to another when soceities/ groups come in contact<br>- Can be heterogenetic (external) such as war, cultural contact, trade etc or orthogenetic (internal) such as stress, innovation, regime change<br>- Scientific factors – Ogburn – cultural lag – tech has an imp role in social change<br>    - Cultural lag means the delay in change in non-material elements after change in material elements<br>    - ![Socio_Paper 1](<Z9 Obsidian-files/Media/DOCX/Socio_Paper 1 102.png>)Eg – a women may work and earn but her position in the family may remain the same<br>    - Empower people eg
